div2.stage: THE SCENE LONDON .
PROLOGVE.

sp.l: Though need make many Poets, and some such
As art&H0;, and nature have not bettered much;
Yet ours&Htp;, for&H4; want, hath not so&H51; loved the stage,
As he dare serve the ill customs of the age:
Or purchase your delight at such a rate,
As, for&H4; it, he himself must justly hate.
To&H9; make a child, now swaddled, to&H9; proceed
Man, and then shoot up&H5;, in&H4; one beard, and weed,
Past threescore years: or, with three rusty swords,
And help of some few foot-and-half-foot words,
Fight over Yorke, and Lancasters long jars:
And in&H4; the trying-house bring wounds, to&H4; scars.
He rather prays, you will&H1; be pleased to&H9; see
One such, today, as other plays should be.
Where neither Chorus wafts you over the seas;
Nor creaking throne comes down, the boys to&H9; please;
Nor nimble squib is seen, to&H9; make afeared
The gentlewomen; nor rolled bullet heard
To&H9; say, it thunders; nor tempestuous drum
Stumbles, to&H9; tell you when the storm doth come;
But deeds, and language, such as men do use:
And persons, such as Comedy would choose,
When she would show an Image of the times,
And sport with human follies, not with crimes.
Except, we&Htp; make them such by&H4; loving still
Our&Htp; popular errors, when we&Htp; know they are ill.
I mean such errors, as you will&H1; all confess
By&H4; laughing at them, they deserve no&H2; less:
Which&H61; when you heartily do, there is hope left, then,
You, that&H61; have so&H52; graced monsters, may like&H1; men.

div2.stage:
Main text
Act I. Scene I.
Kno'well, Brayne-Worme, M r Stephen.

sp.p: A Goodly day toward! and a fresh morning! Brayne-Worme, Call up&H5; your young master: bid him rise, sir. Tell him, I have some business to&H9; employ him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I will&H1; sir, presently.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: But hear you, sirrah,
If he be at his book, disturb him not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: How happy, yet, should I esteem myself
Could I (by&H4; any practise) wean the boy
From one vain course of study, he affects.
He is a scholar, if a man may trust
The liberal voice of fame, in&H4; her&H2; report
Of good accompt, in&H4; both our&Htp; universities,
Either of which&H61; hath favoured him with graces:
But their indulgence, must not spring in&H4; me
A fond opinion, that&H3; he cannot err.
Myself was once a student; and, indeed,
Fed with the selfsame humour, he is now,
Dreaming on&H4; nought but idle poetry,
That&H62; fruitless, and unprofitable art&H0;,
Good unto none, but least to&H4; the professors,
Which&H61;, then, I thought the mistress of all knowledge:
But since, time, and the truth have waked my judgment,
And reason taught me better to&H9; distinguish,
[25] The vain, from the useful learnings. Cousin Stephen!
What news with you, that&H3; you are here so&H51; early?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Nothing, but even come to&H9; see how you do, uncle.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: That&H62; is kindly done, you are welcome, cuz.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Aye, I know that&H62; sir, I would not have come else. How do my cousin Edward, uncle?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: O, well cuz, go in&H5; and see: I doubt he be scarce stirring yet.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Uncle, afore I go in&H5;, can you tell me, if he have ere a book of the sciences of hawking, and hunting? I would fain borrow it.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Why, I hope you will&H1; not ahawking now, will&H1; you?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: No&H7; wuss; but I will&H1; practise against next year uncle: I have bought me a hawk, and a hood, and bells, and all; I lack nothing but a book to&H9; keep it by&H5;.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: O, most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, look you now, you are angry, uncle: why you know, if a man have not skill in&H4; the hawking, and hunting-languages now adays, I will&H1; not give a rush for&H4; him. They are more studied than the Greek, or the Latin. He is for&H4; no&H2; gallants company without them. And by&H4; gads did I scorn it, Aye, so&H52; I do, to&H9; be a consort for&H4; every hum-drum, hang them scrolls, there is nothing in&H4; them, in&H4; the world. What do you talk on&H4; it? Because I dwell at Hogsden, I shall keep company with none but the archers of Finsburie? or the citizens, that&H61; come a ducking to&H4; Islington ponds? A fine jest i'faith! 'slid a gentleman mun show himself like&H4; a gentleman. Uncle, I pray you be not angry, I know what I have to&H9; do, I trow, I am no&H2; novice.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: [50] You are a prodigal absurd coxcomb: Go to&H5;.
Nay never look at me, it is I that&H61; speak.
Take it as you will&H1; sir, I will&H1; not flatter you.
Have you not yet found means enough, to&H9; waste.
That&H62;, which&H61; your friends have left you, but you must
Go cast away your money on&H4; a kite,
And know not how to&H9; keep it, when you have done?
O it is comely! this will&H1; make you a gentleman!
Well cousin, well! I see you are even past hope
Of all reclaim. Aye, so&H3;, now you are told on&H4; it,
You look another way.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: What would I have you do? I will&H1; tell you kinsman,
Learn to&H9; be wise, and practise how to&H9; thrive,
That&H62; would I have you do: and not to&H9; spend
Your coin on&H4; every babble, that&H61; you fancy,
Or every foolish brain, that&H61; humours you.
I would not have you to&H9; invade each place,
Nor thrust yourself on&H4; all societies,
Till men's affections, or your own desert,
Should worthily invite you to&H4; your rank.
He, that&H61; is so&H51; respectless in&H4; his courses,
Oft sells his reputation, at cheap market.
Nor would I, you should melt away yourself
In&H4; flashing bravery, lest while you affect
[75] To&H9; make a blaze of gentry to&H4; the world,
A little puff of scorn extinguish it,
And you be left, like&H4; an unsavoury snuff,
Whose property is only to&H9; offend.
I would have you sober, and contain yourself;
Not, that&H3; your sail be bigger than your boat:
But moderate your expenses now (at first)
As you may keep the same proportion still.
Nor, stand so&H51; much on&H4; your gentility,
Which&H61; is an aërie, and mere borrowed thing,
From dead men's dust, and bones: and none of yours
Except you make, or hold it. Who&H62; comes here?

div2.stage:
Act. I. Scene II.
Servant, M r. Stephen, Kno'well, Brayne-Worme.

sp.p: Save you, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, we&Htp; do not stand much on&H4; our&Htp; gentility, friend; yet, you are welcome, and I assure you, mine uncle here is a man of a thousand a year, Middlesex land: he has but one son in&H4; all the world, I am his next heir (at the common law) master Stephen, as simple as I stand here, if my cousin die (as there is hope he will&H1;) I have a pretty living of mine own too, beside, hard-by here.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: In&H4; good time, sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: In&H4; good time, sir? why! and in&H4; very good time, sir. You do not slout, friend, do you?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Not you, sir? you were not best, sir; if you should, here be them can perceive it, and that&H62; quickly too: go to&H5;. And they can give it again soundly too, if need be.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why, sir, let this satisfy you: good faith, I had no&H2; such intent.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Sir, if I thought you had, I would talk with you, and that&H62; presently.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Good master Stephen, so&H52; you may, sir, at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: And so&H52; I would sir, good my saucy companion! if you were out of mine uncles ground, I can tell you; though I do not stand upon&H4; my gentility neither in&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Cousin! cousin! will&H1; this never be left?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Whoreson base fellow! a mechanical serving-man! By&H4; this cudgel, if it were not for&H4; shame, I would---

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: [25] What would you do, you peremptory gull?
If you cannot be quiet, get you hence.
You see, the honest man demeans himself
Modestly towards you, giving no&H2; reply
To&H4; your unseasoned, quarrelling, rude fashion:
And, still you huff it, with a kind of carriage,
As void of wit, as of humanity.
Go, get you in&H5;; fore heaven, I am ashamed
Thou hast a kinsman's interest in&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I pray you, sir. Is this master Kno'well's house?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Yes, marry, is it sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
I should enquire for&H4; a gentleman, here, one master Edward
Kno'well : do you know any such, sir, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: I should forget myself else, sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Are you the gentleman? cry you mercy sir: I was required by&H4; a gentleman in&H4; the city, as I rode out at this end of the town, to&H9; deliver you this letter, sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: To&H4; me, sir! What do you mean? pray you remember your courtesy. (To&H4; his most selected friend, master Edward Kno'well.) What might the gentleman's name be, sir, that&H61; sent it? nay, pray you be covered.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: One master Well-bred, sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Master Well-bred! A young gentleman? is he not?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The same sir, master Kitely married his sister: the rich merchant in&H4; the old Jewry.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: You say very true. Braine-worme,

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Make this honest friend drink here: pray you go in&H5;.
This letter is directed to&H4; my son:
Yet, I am Edward Kno'well too, and may
With the safe conscience of good manners, use
The fellows error to&H4; my satisfaction.
Well, I will&H1; break it ope (old men are curious)
Be it but for&H4; the stiles sake, and the phrase,
To&H9; see, if both do answer my sons praises,
Who&H61; is, almost, grown the idolater
Of this young Well-bred: what have we&Htp; here? what is this?

div2.stage: The letter.

sp.p:
Why, Ned, I beseech thee; hast thou for-sworn all thy friends in&H4; the old Jewry? or dost thou think us&Htp; all Jews that&H61; inhabit there, yet? If thou dost, come over, and but see our&Htp; frippery: change an old shirt, for&H4; a whole smock, with us&Htp;. Do not conceive that&H62; antipathy between us&Htp;, and Hogs-den; as was between Jews, and hogs-flesh. Leave thy vigilant father, alone, to&H9; number over his green apricots, evening, and morning, of the north-west wall: If I had been his son, I had saved him the labour, long since; if, taking in&H5; all the young wenches, that&H61; pass by&H5;, at the backdoor, and coddling every kernel of the fruit for&H4; them, would have served. But, pray thee, come over to&H4; me, quickly, this morning: I have such a present for&H4; thee (our&Htp; Turkey company never sent the like&H0; to&H4; the Grand-Signior.) One is a Rhymer sir, of your own batch, your own leven; but doth think himself Poet-major, of the town: willing to&H9; be shown, and worthy [75] to&H9; be seen. The other---I will&H1; not venture his description with you, till you come, because I would have you make hither with an appetite. If the worst of them be not worth your journey, draw your bill of charges,
as unconscionable, as any Guild-hall verdict will&H1; give it you, and you shall be allowed your viaticum. From the wind-mill.

sp.l: From the Bordello, it might come as well;
The Spittle: or Pict-hatch. Is this the man,
My son hath sung so&H52;, for&H4; the happiest wit,
The choicest brain, the times hath sent us&Htp; forth?
I know not what he may be, in&H4; the arts;
Nor what in&H4; schools: but surely, for&H4; his manners,
I judge him a profane, and dissolute wretch:
Worse, by&H4; possession of such great good gifts,
Being the master of so&H51; loose a spirit.
Why, what unhallowed ruffian would have writ,
In&H4; such a scurrilous manner, to&H4; a friend!
Why should he think, I tell my Apricots?
Or play the Hesperian Dragon, with my fruit,
To&H9; watch it? Well my son, I had thought
You had had more judgment, to&H9; have made election
Of your companions, than to&H9; have taken on&H4; trust,
Such petulant, jeering gamesters, that&H61; can spare
No&H2; argument, or subject from their jest.
But I perceive, affection makes a fool
Of any man, too much the father. Brayne-worme,

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Is the fellow gone that&H61; brought this letter?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Yes, sir, a pretty while since.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: And, where is your young master?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: In&H4; his chamber sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: He spake not with the fellow! did he?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: No&H7; sir, he saw him not.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Take you this letter, and deliver it my son
But with no&H2; notice, that&H3; I have opened it, on&H4; your life.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: O lord, sir, that&H62; were a jest, indeed!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: I am resolved, I will&H1; not stop his journey;
Nor practise any violent mean, to&H9; stay
The unbridled course of youth in&H4; him: for&H3; that&H62;,
Restrained, grows more impatient; and, in&H4; kind,
Like&H5; to&H4; the eager, but the generous grey-hound,
Who&H61; never so&H51; little from his game with-held,
Turns head, and leaps up&H5; at his holders throat.
There is a way of winning, more by&H4; love,
And urging of the modesty, than fear:
Force works on&H4; servile natures, not the free.
He, that&H61; is compelled to&H4; goodness, may be good;
But it is but for&H4; that&H62; fit: where others drawn
By&H4; softness, and example, get a habit.
Then, if they stray, but warn them: and, the same
They should for&H4; virtue have done, they will&H1; do for&H4; shame.

div2.stage:
Act I. Scene II.
Edw. Kno'well, Brayne-worme, M r. Stephen.

sp.p: Did he open it, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Yes, on&H4; my word sir, and read the contents.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: That&H62; scarce contents me. What countenance (pray thee) made he, in&H4; the reading of it? was he angry, or pleased?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nay sir, I saw him not read it, nor open it, I assure your worship.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: No&H7;? how knowest thou, then, that&H3; he did either?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Marry sir, because he charged me, on&H4; my life, to&H9; tell nobody, that&H3; he opened it: which&H61;, unless he had done, he would never fear to&H9; have it revealed.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: That&H62; is true: well I thank thee, Blayne-worme.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O, Brayne-worme, didst thou not see a fellow here in&H4; a what-sha'-call-him doublet! he brought mine uncle a letter e'en now.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Yes, master Stephen, what of him?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O, I have such a mind to&H9; beat him---Where is he? canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith, he is not of that&H62; mind: he is gone, master Stephen.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Gone? which&H62; way? when went he! how long since?
He is rid hence. He took horse, at the street door.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: And, I staid in&H4; the fields! whoreson scander-bag rogue! O that&H3; I had but a horse to&H9; fetch him back again.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Why, you may have my m r s. gelding, to&H9; save your longing, sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: But, I have no&H2; boots, that&H62; is the spite of it.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Why, a fine wisp of hey, rolled hard, master Stephen.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: [25] No&H7; faith, it is no&H2; boot to&H9; follow him, now: let him even go, and hang. Pray thee, help to&H9; truss me, a little. He does so&H51; vex me---

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: You will&H1; be worse vexed, when you are trussed, master Stephen. Best, keep unbraced; and walk yourself, till you be cold: your choler may founder you else.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: By&H4; my faith, and so&H52; I will&H1;, now thou tellest me of it: How dost thou like&H1; my leg, Brayne-worme?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: A very good leg! master Stephen! but the woollen stocking does not commend it so&H51; well.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p:
Foh, the stockings be good enough, now summer is coming or for&H4; the dust: I will&H1; have a pair of silk, against winter, that&H61; I go to&H9; dwell
in&H4; the town. I think my leg would show in&H4; a silk hose.

sp.speaker: Brap.
sp.p: Believe me, master Stephen, rarely well,

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: In&H4; sadness, I think it would: I have a reasonable good leg.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: You have an excellent good leg, master Stephen, but cannot stay, to&H9; praise it longer now, and I am very sorry for&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Another time will&H1; serve, Brayne-worme. Gramercy for&H4; this

div2.stage: Knowell laughes having read the letter.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: 'slid, I hope, he laughs not at me, if he doe---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Here was a letter, indeed, to&H9; be intercepted by&H4; a man's father and do him good with him! He cannot but think most virtuously both of me, and the sender, sure; that&H61; make the careful Costar-monger of him in&H4; our&Htp; familiar Epistles. Well, if he read this with patience, I will&H1; be-gilt and troll ballads for&H4; M r. Iohn Trvndle, yonder, the rest of my mortality. It is true, and likely, my father may have as much patience as another [50] man; for&H3; he takes much physic: and, oft taking physic makes a man very patient. But would your packet, master Wel-bred, had arrived at him, in&H4; such a minute of his patience; then, we&Htp; had known the end of it, which&H61; now is doubtful, and threatens---What! my wise cousin! Nay, then, I will&H1; furnish our&Htp; feast with one gull more toward the mess. He writes to&H4; me of a brace, and here is one, that&H62; is three: O, for&H4; a fourth; Fortune, if ever thou wilt use thine eyes, I entreat thee---

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O, now I see, who&H61; he laugh at. He laughed at some-body in&H4; that&H62; letter. By&H4; this good light, if he had laughed at me---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How now, cousin Stephen, melancholy?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Yes a little. I thought, you had laughed at me, cousin.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Why, what if I had cuz, what would you have done?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: By&H4; this light, I would have told mine uncle.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, if you wold have told your uncle, I did laugh at you, cuz.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Did you, indeed?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, then---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I am satisfied, it is sufficient.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Why, be so&H52; gentle cuz. And, I pray you let me entreat a courtesy of you. I am sent for&H5;, this morning, by&H4; a friend in&H4; the old Jewry to&H9; come to&H4; him; It is but crossing over the fields to&H4; More-gate: Will&H1; you bear me company? I protest, it is not to&H9; draw you into bond, or any plot against the state, cuz.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Sir, that&H62; is all one, if it were; you shall command me, twice [75] so&H51; far as More-gate to&H9; do you good, in&H4; such a matter. Do you think I would leave you? I protest---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: No&H7;, no&H7;, you shall not protest, cuz.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: By&H4; my fackins, but I will&H1;, by&H4; your leave; I will&H1; protest more to&H4; my friend, than I will&H1; speak off, at this time.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: You speak very well, cuz.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, not so&H52; neither, you shall pardon me: but I speak, to&H9; serve my turn.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Your turn, cuz? Do you know, what you say? A gentleman of your sort, parts, carriage, and estimation, to&H9; talk of your turn in&H4; this company, and to&H4; me, alone, like&H4; a tankard-bearer, at a conduit! Fie. A wight, that&H61; (hitherto) his every step hath left the stamp of a great foot behind him, as every word the savour of a strong spirit! and he! this man! so&H51; graced, gilded, or (to&H9; use a more fit metaphor) so&H51; tinfoiled by&H4; nature, as not ten house-wives pewter (again a good time) shows more bright to&H4; the world than he! and he (as I said last, so&H52; I say again, and still shall say it) this man! to&H9; conceal such real ornaments as these, and shadow their glory, as a Milliners wife does her&H2; wrought stomacher, with a smoky lawn, or a black cypress? O cuz! It cannot be answered, go not about it. Drakes old ship, at Detford, may sooner circle the world again. Come, wrong not the quality of your desert, with looking downward, cuz; but hold up&H5; your head, so&H52;: and let the Idea of what you are, be portrayed in&H4; your face, that&H3; men may read in&H4; your physiognomy, (Here, within this place, is to&H9; be seen the true, rare, and accomplished monster, or miracle of nature, which&H61; is all one.) What think you of this, cuz?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: [100] Why, I do think of it; and I will&H1; be more proud, and melancholy, and gentleman-like, than I have been: I will&H1; ensure you.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Why, that&H62; is resolute master Stephen! Now, if I can but told him up&H5; to&H4; his height, as it is happily begun, it will&H1; do well for&H4; a suburb-humour: we&Htp; may hap have a match with the city, and play him for&H4; forty pound. Come, cuz.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I will&H1; follow you.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Follow me? you must go before.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, if I must, I will&H1;. Pray you, show me, good cousin.

div2.stage:
Act I. Scene IIII.
M r. Matthew, Cob.

sp.p: Think, this be the house: what, hock?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Who&H62; is there? O, master Matthew! give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What! Cob! how dost thou, good Cob? dost thou inhabit here, Cob?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Aye, sir, I and my linage have kept a poor house, here, in&H4; our&Htp; days.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thy linage, Monsieur Cob, what linage? what linage?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p:
Why sir, an ancient linage, and a princely. Mine ancestry came from a Kings belly, no&H2; worse man: and yet no&H2; man neither (by&H4; your worships leave, I did lie in&H4; that&H62;) but Herring the King of fish (from his belly, I proceed) one of the Monarchs of the world, I assure you. The first red herring, that&H61; was broiled in&H4; Adam, and Eve's kitchen, do I fetch my
pedigree from, by&H4; the Harrots books. His Cob, was my great-great-mighty-great Grand father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why mighty? why mighty? I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, it was a mighty while ago, sir, and a mighty great Cob.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How knowest thou that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How know I? why, I smell his ghost, ever and anon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Smell a ghost? O unsavoury jest! and the ghost of a herring Cob!

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Aye sir, with favour of your worships nose, M r. Mathew, why not the ghost of a herring-cob, as well as the ghost of rasher-bacon?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Roger Bacon, thou wouldst say?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I say rasher-bacon. They were both broiled of the coals? and [25] a man may smell broiled-meat, I hope? you are a scholar, upsolve me that&H62;, now.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O raw ignorance! Cob, canst thou show me of a gentleman, one Captain Bobadill, where his lodging is?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, my guest, sir! you mean.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thy guest! Alas! ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Why do you laugh, sir? Do you not mean Captain Bobadill?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Cob, pray thee, advise thyself well: do not wrong the gentleman, and thyself too. I dare be sworn, he scorns thy house: he! He lodge in&H4; such a base, obscure place, as thy house! Tut, I know his disposition so&H51; well, he would not lie in&H4; thy bed, if thou wouldst give it him.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I will&H1; not give it him, though, sir. Mass, I thought somewhat was in&H4; it, we&Htp; could not get him to&H4; bed, all night! Well, sir, though he lie not of my bed, he lies of my bench: if it please you to&H9; go up&H5;, sir, you shall find him with two cushions under his head, and his cloak wrapped about him, as though he had neither won nor lost, and yet (I warrant) he never cast better in&H4; his life, than he has done, tonight.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why? was he drunk?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Drunk, sir? you hear not me say so&H52;. Perhaps, he swallowed a tavern-token, or some such device, sir: I have nothing to&H9; do withal. I deal with water, and not with wine. Give me my tankard there, hock. God be with you, sir. It is six o'clock: I should have carried two turns, by&H4; this. What hock? my stopple? come.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Lie in&H4; a water-bearers house! A gentleman of his havings! Well, I will&H1; tell him my mind.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p:
[50] What Tib, show this gentleman up&H5; to&H4; the Captain. O, if my house were the Brazen-head now! faith, it would even speak, Mo fools yet. You should have some now would take this M r. Matthew to&H9; be a gentleman, at the least. His father is an honest man, a worshipful fishmonger, and so&H52; forth; and now does he creep, and wriggle into acquaintance with all the brave gallants about the town, such as my guest is: (O, my guest is a fine man) and they flout him invincibly. He useth
every day to&H4; a Merchants house (where I serve water) one master Kitely's, in&H4; the old Jewry; and here is the jest, he is in&H4; love with my masters sister, (mistress Bridget) and calls her&H6; mistress: and there he will&H1; sit you a whole afternoon some-times, reading of these same abominable, vile, (a pox on&H4; them, I cannot abide them) rascally verses, poetry, poetry, and speaking of interludes, it will&H1; make a man burst to&H9; hear him. And the wenches, they do so&H52; jeer, and ti-he at him---well, should they do so&H51; much to&H4; me, I would forswear them all, by&H4; the foot of Pharaoh. There is an oath! How many water-bearers shall you hear swear such an oath? O, I have a guest (he teaches me) he does swear the legiblest, of any man christened: By&H4; S t. George, the foot of Pharaoh, the body of me, as I am gentleman, and a soldier: such dainty oaths! and withal, he does take this same filthy roguish tobacco, the finest, and cleanliest! it would do a man good to&H9; see the fume come forth at his tunnels! Well, he owes me forty shillings (my wife lent him out of her&H2; purse, by&H4; sixpence a time) besides his lodging: I would I had it. I shall have it, he says, the next Action. Helter skelter, hang sorrow, care will&H1; kill a cat, uptails all, and a louse for&H4; the hang-man.

div2.stage:
Act I. Scene V.
Bobadill, Tib, Matthew. Bobad. is discouered lying on his bench.

sp.p: Hostess, hostess.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: What say you, sir?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A cup of thy small beer, sweet hostess.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Sir, there is a gentleman, below, would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A gentleman! odds so&H52;, I am not within.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: My husband told him you were, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: What a plague---what meant he?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Captain Bobadill?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Who&H62; is there? (take away the basin, good hostess) come up&H5;, sir.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: He would desire you to&H9; come up&H5;, sir. You come into a cleanly house, here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Save you, sir. Save you, Captain.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Gentle master Matthew! Is it you, sir? Please you sit down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thank you, good Captain, you may see, I am some-what audacious.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Not so&H52;, sir. I was requested to&H4; supper, last night, by&H4; a sort of gallants, where you were wished for&H5;, and drunk to&H5;, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Vouchsafe me, by&H4; whom, good Captain.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Marry, by&H4; young Well-bred, and others: Why, hostess, a stool here for&H4; this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No&H2; haste, sir, it is very well.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Body of me! It was so&H51; late ere we&Htp; parted last night, I can scarce open my eyes, yet; I was but new risen, as you came: how passes the day abroad, sir? you can tell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: [25] Faith, some half hour to&H4; seven: now trust me, you have an exceeding fine lodging here, very neat, and private!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Aye, sir: sit down, I pray you. Master Matthew (in&H4; any case) possess no&H2; gentlemen of our&Htp; acquaintance, with notice of my lodging.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Who&H62;? I sir? no&H7;.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Not that&H3; I need to&H9; care who&H61; know it, for&H3; the Cabin is convenient, but in&H4; regard I would not be too popular, and generally visited, as some are.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: True, Captain, I conceive you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: For&H3;, do you see, sir, by&H4; the heart of valour, in&H4; me, (except it be to&H4; some peculiar and choice spirits, to&H4; whom I am extraordinarily engaged, as yourself, or so&H52;) I could not extend thus far.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O Lord, sir, I resolve so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I confess, I love a cleanly and quiet privacy, above all the tumult, and roar of fortune. What new book have you there? What! Go by&H5;, Hieronymo!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Aye, did you ever see it acted? is it not well penned?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Well penned? I would fain see all the Poets, of these times, pen such another play as that&H62; was! they will&H1; prate and swagger, and keep a stir of art&H0; and devices, when (as I am a gentleman) read them, they are the most shallow, pitiful, barren fellows, that&H61; live upon&H4; the face of the earth, again!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Indeed, here are a number of fine speeches in&H4; this book! O eyes, no&H2; eyes, but fountains fraught with tears! There is a conceit! fountains fraught with tears! O life, no&H2; life, but lively form of death! Another! O [50] world, no&H2; world, but mass of public wrongs! A third! Confused and filled with murder, and misdeeds! A fourth! O, the Muses! Is it not excellent? Is it not simply the best that&H61; ever you heard, Captain? Ha? How do you like&H1; it?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: It is good.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: To&H4; thee, the purest object to&H4; my sense,
The most refined essence heaven covers,
Send I these lines, wherein I do commence
The happy state of turtle-billing lovers.
If they prove rough, unpolished, harsh, and rude,
Haste made the waste. Thus, mildly, I conclude.
Bobadill is making him ready all this while.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Nay, proceed, proceed. Where is this?

sp.speaker: Mat.
Bob.
sp.p: So&H52;, so&H52;, It is the fashion, gentlemen now use.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Troth, Captain, if now you speak of the fashion, master Well-bred's elder brother, and I, are fallen out exceedingly: this other day, I happened to&H9; enter into some discourse of a hanger, which&H61; I assure you, both for&H4; fashion, and workmanship, was most peremptory-beautiful,
and gentleman-like! Yet, he condemned, and cried it down, for&H4; the most pied, and ridiculous that&H61; ever he saw.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Squire Downe-right? the half-brother? was it not?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Aye sir, he.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Hang him, rook, he! why, he has no&H2; more judgment than a [75] malt-horse. By&H4; S. George, I wonder you would loose a thought upon&H4; such an animal: the most peremptory absurd clown of christendom, this day, he is holden. I protest to&H4; you, as I am a gentleman, and a soldier, I never changed words, with his like&H0;. By&H4; his discourse, he should eat nothing but hey. He was born for&H4; the manger, pannier, or pack-saddle! He has not so&H51; much as a good phrase in&H4; his belly, but all old iron, and rusty proverbs! a good commodity for&H4; some smith, to&H9; make hob-nails of.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Aye, and he thinks to&H9; carry it away with his man-hood still, where he comes. He brags he will&H1; give me the bastinado, as I hear.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: How! He the bastinado! how came he by&H4; that&H62; word, trow?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Nay, indeed, he said cudgel me; I termed it so&H52;, for&H4; my more grace.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: That&H62; may be: For&H3; I was sure, it was none of his word. But, when? when said he so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Faith, yesterday, they say: a young gallant, a friend of mine told me so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: By&H4; the foot of Pharaoh, if it were my case now, I should send him a chartel, presently. The bastinado! A most proper, and sufficient dependence, warranted by&H4; the great Caranza. Come hither. You shall chartel him. I will&H1; show you a trick, or two, you shall kill him with, at pleasure: the first stoccata, if you will&H1;, by&H4; this air.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Indeed, you have absolute knowledge in&H4; the mystery, I have heard, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Of whom? Of whom have you heard it, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Troth, I have heard it spoken of divers, that&H3; you have very [100] rare, and un-in-one-breath-utter-able skill, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: By&H4; heaven, no&H7;, not I; no&H2; skill in&H4; the earth: some small rudiments in&H4; the science, as to&H9; know my time, distance, or so&H52;. I have professed it more for&H4; noblemen, and gentlemen's use, than mine own practise, I assure you. Hostess, accommodate us&Htp; with another bed-staff here, quickly: Lend us&Htp; another bed-staff. The woman does not understand the words of Action. Look you, sir. Exalt not your point above this state, at any hand, and let your poniard maintain your defence, thus: (give it the gentleman, and leave us&Htp;) so&H52;, sir. Come on&H5;: O, twine your body more about, that&H3; you may fall to&H4; a more sweet comely gentleman-like guard. So&H3;, indifferent. Hollow your body more sir, thus. Now, stand fast on&H4; your left leg, note your distance, keep your due proportion of time--- O, you disorder your point, most irregularly!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How is the bearing of it, now, sir?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: O, out of measure ill! A well-experienced hand would pass upon&H4; you, at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How mean you, sir, pass upon&H4; me?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why, thus sir (make a thrust at me) come in&H5;, upon&H4; the answer, control your point, and make a full career, at the body. The best-practised gallants of the time, name it the passada: a most desperate thrust, believe it!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well, come, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why, you do not manage your weapon with any facility, or grace to&H9; invite me: I have no&H2; spirit to&H9; play with you. Your dearth of judgment renders you tedious.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: [125] But one venue, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Venue! Fie. Most gross denomination, as ever I heard. O, the stoccata, while you live, sir. Note that&H62;. Come, put on&H5; your cloak, and we&Htp; will&H1; go to&H4; some private place, where you are acquainted, some tavern, or so&H52;---and have a bit---I will&H1; send for&H4; one of these Fencers, and he shall breath you, by&H4; my direction; and, then, I will&H1; teach you your trick. You shall kill him with it, at the first, if you please. Why, I will&H1; learn you, by&H4; the true judgment of the eye, hand, and foot, to&H9; control any enemies point in&H4; the world. Should your adversary confront you with a pistol, it were nothing, by&H4; this hand, you should, by&H4; the same rule, control his bullet, in&H4; a line: except it were hail shot, and spread. What money have you about you, M r. Matthew?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Faith, I have not past a two shillings, or so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Bob.

div2.stage:
Act II. Scene I.
Kitely, Cash, Downe-right.

sp.l: Thomas, Come hither,
There lies a note, within upon&H4; my desk,
Here, take my key: It is no&H2; matter, neither.
Where is the Boy?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Within, sir, in&H4; the ware-house.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Let him tell over, straight, that&H62; Spanish gold,
And weigh it, with the pieces of eight. Do you
See the delivery of those silver stuffs,
To&H4; M r. Lvcar. Tell him, if he will&H1;,
He shall have the grogran's, at the rate I told him,
And I will&H1; meet him, on&H4; the Exchange, anon.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Good, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Do you see that&H62; fellow, brother Downe-right?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Aye, what of him?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: He is a jewel, brother.
I took him of a child, up&H5;, at my door,
And christened him, gave him mine own name, Thomas,
Since bred him at the Hospital; where proving
A toward imp, I called him home, and taught him
So&H51; much, as I have made him my Cashier,
And given him, who&H61; had none, a surname, Cash:
And find him, in&H4; his place so&H51; full of faith,
That&H3;, I durst trust my life into his hands.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: So&H3;, would not I in&H4; any bastards, brother,
[25] As, it is like&H5;, he is: although I knew
Myself his father. But you said you had somewhat
To&H9; tell me, gentle brother, what is it? what is it?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Faith, I am very loath, to&H9; utter it,
As fearing, it may hurt your patience:
But, that&H3; I know, your judgment is of strength,
Against the nearness of affection---

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: What need this circumstance? pray you be direct.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I will&H1; not say, how much I do ascribe
Unto your friendship; nor, in&H4; what regard
I hold your love: but, let my past behaviour,
And usage of your sister, but confirm
How well I have been affected to&H4; your---

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: You are too tedious, come to&H4; the matter, the matter.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Then (without further ceremony) thus.
My brother Well-bred, sir, (I know not how)
Of late, is much declined in&H4; what he was,
And greatly altered in&H4; his disposition.
When he came first to&H9; lodge here in&H4; my house,
never trust me, if I were not proud of him:
Methought he bare himself in&H4; such a fashion,
So&H51; full of man, and sweetness in&H4; his carriage,
And (what was chief) it showed not borrowed in&H4; him,
But all he did, became him as his own,
And seemed as perfect, proper, and possessed
[50] As breath, with life, or colour, with the blood.
But, now, his course is so&H51; irregular,
So&H51; loose, affected, and deprived of grace,
And he himself withal so&H51; far fallen off
From that&H62; first place, as scarce no&H2; note remains,
To&H9; tell men's judgments where he lately stood.
He is grown a stranger to&H4; all due respect,
Forgetful of his friends, and not content
To&H9; stale himself in&H4; all societies,
He makes my house here common, as a Mart,
A Theatre, a public receptacle
For&H4; giddy humour, and diseased riot;
And here (as in&H4; a tavern, or a stews)
He, and his wild associates, spend their hours,
In&H4; repetition of lascivious jests,
Swear, leap, drink, dance, and revel night by&H4; night,
Control my servants: and indeed what not?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: 'Sdeynes, I know not what I should say to&H4; him, in&H4; the whole world! He values me, at a cracked three-farthings, for&H4; aught I see: It will&H1; never out of the flesh that&H61; is bred in&H4; the bone! I have told him enough, one would think, if that&H62; would serve: But, counsel to&H4; him, is as good, as a shoulder of mutton to&H4; a sick horse. Well! he knows what to&H9; trust to&H5;, for&H4; George. Let him spend, and spend, and domineer, till his heart ache; if he think to&H9; be relieved by&H4; me, when he is got into one of your city pounds, the Counters, he has the wrong sow by&H4; the ear, i'faith: and [75] claps his dish at the wrong man's door. I will&H1; lay my hand of my halfpenny, ere I part with it, to&H9; fetch him out, I will&H1; assure him.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Nay, good brother, let it not trouble you, thus.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, he mads me, I could eat my very spur leathers, for&H4; anger! But, why are you so&H51; tame? Why do not you speak to&H4; him, and tell him how he disquiets your house?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: O, there are divers reasons to&H9; dissuade, brother.
But, would yourself vouchsafe to&H9; travail in&H4; it,
(Though but with plain, and easy circumstance)
It would, both come much better to&H4; his sense,
And savour less of stomach, or of passion.
You are his elder brother, and that&H62; title
Both gives, and warrants you authority;
Which&H61; (by&H4; your presence seconded) must breed
A kind of duty in&H4; him, and regard:
Whereas, if I should intimate the least,
It would but add contempt, to&H4; his neglect,
Heap worse on&H4; ill, make up&H5; a pile of hatred
That&H61;, in&H4; the rearing, would come tottering down,
And, in&H4; the ruin, bury all our&Htp; love.
Nay, more than this, brother, if I should speak
He would be ready from his heat of humour,
And over-flowing of the vapour, in&H4; him,
To&H9; blow the ears of his familiars,
With the false breath, of telling, what disgraces,
[100] And low disparagement, I had put upon&H4; him.
Whilst they, sir, to&H9; relieve him, in&H4; the fable,
Make their loose comments, upon&H4; every word,
Gesture, or look, I use; mock me all over,
From my flat cap, unto my shining shoes:
And, out of their impetuous rioting phantasies,
Beget some slander, that&H61; shall dwell with me.
And what would that&H62; be, think you? marry, this.
They would give out (because my wife is fair,
Myself but lately married, and my sister
Here sojourning a virgin in&H4; my house)
That&H3; I were jealous! nay, as sure as death,
That&H62; they would say. And how that&H3; I had quarrelled
My brother purposely, thereby to&H9; find
An apt pretext, to&H9; banish them my house.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Mass perhaps so&H52;: They are like&H5; enough to&H9; do it.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Brother, they would, believe it: so&H3; should I
(Like&H4; one of these penurious quack salvers)
But set the bills up&H5;, to&H4; mine own disgrace,
And try experiments upon&H4; myself:
Lend scorn and envy, opportunity,
To&H9; stab my reputation, and good name---

div2.stage:
Act II. Scene II.
Matthew, Bobadil, Downe-right, Kitely.

sp.p: I will&H1; speak to&H4; him---

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Speak to&H4; him? away, by&H4; the foot of Pharaoh, you shall not, you shall not do him that&H62; grace. The time of day, to&H4; you, Gentleman of the house. Is Mr. Well-bred stirring?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: How then? what should he do?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Gentleman of the house, it is to&H4; you: is he within, sir?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: He came not to&H4; his lodging tonight sir, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Why, do you hear? you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: The gentleman-citizen hath satisfied me, I will&H1; talk to&H4; no&H2; scavenger.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: How, scavenger? stay sir, stay?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Nay, brother Downe-right.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: 'sheart! stand you away, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: You shall not follow him now, I pray you, brother,
Good faith you shall not: I will&H1; over-rule you.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Ha? scavenger? well, go to&H5;, I say little: but, by&H4; this good day (god forgive me I should swear) if I put it up&H5; so&H52;, say, I am the rankest cow, that&H61; ever pissed. 'Sdeynes, if I swallow this, I will&H1; never draw my sword in&H4; the sight of Fleet-street again, while I live; I will&H1; sit in&H4; a barn, with Madge-howlet, and catch mice first. Scavenger? 'sheart, if I will&H1; go near to&H9; fill that&H62; huge tumbrel-slop of yours, with somewhat, if I have good luck: your Garagantva breech cannot carry it away so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: O do not fret yourself thus, never think on&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: These are my brothers consorts, these! these are his Comrades, his walking mates! he is a gallant, a Cavalier too, right hang-man cut! [25] Let me not live, if I could not find in&H4; my heart to&H9; swing the whole ging of them, one after another, and begin with him first. I am grieved, it should be said he is my brother, and take these courses. Well, as he brews, so&H3; he shall drink, for&H4; George, again. Yet, he shall hear of it, and that&H62; tightly too, if I live, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: But, brother, let your reprehension (then)
Run in&H4; an easy current, not over-high
Carried with rashness, or devouring choler;
But rather use the soft persuading way,
Whose powers will&H1; work more gently, and compose
The imperfect thoughts you labour to&H9; reclaim:
More winning, than enforcing the consent.

div2.stage: Bell rings.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, let me alone for&H4; that&H62;, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: How now? O, the bell rings to&H4; breakfast.
Brother, I pray you go in&H5;, and bear my wife
Company, till I come; I will&H1; but give order
For&H4; some dispatch of business, to&H4; my seruants---

div2.stage:
Act II. Scene III.
To them. Kitely, Cob, Dame Kitely.

sp.l: What, Cob? our&Htp; maids will&H1; have you by&H4; the back (I'faith)
For&H4; coming so&H51; late this morning.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Perhaps so&H52;, sir, take heed somebody have not them by&H4; the belly, for&H4; walking so&H51; late in&H4; the evening.

div2.stage: He passes by with his tankard.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Well, yet my troubled spirit's somewhat eased,
Though not reposed in&H4; that&H62; security,
As I could wish: But, I must be content.
How ever I set a face on&H4; it to&H4; the world,
Would I had lost this finger, at a venture,
So&H3; Well-bred had never lodged within my house.
Why it cannot be, where there is such resort
Of wanton gallants, and young revellers,
That&H3; any woman should be honest long.
Is it like&H5;, that&H3; factious beauty will&H1; preserve
The public weal of chastity, un-shaken,
When such strong motives muster, and make head
Against her&H2; single peace? no&H7;, no&H7;. Beware,
When mutual appetite doth meet to&H9; treat,
And spirits of one kind, and quality,
Come once to&H9; parley, in&H4; the pride of blood:
It is no&H2; slow conspiracy, that&H61; follows.
Well (to&H9; be plain) if I but thought, the time
Had answered their affections: all the world
Should not persuade me, but I were a cuckold.
[25] Marry, I hope, they have not got that&H62; start:
For&H3; opportunity hath balked them yet,
And shall do still, while I have eyes, and ears
To&H9; attend the impositions of my heart.
My presence shall be as an iron bar,
Betwixt the conspiring motions of desire:
Yea, every look, or glance, mine eye ejects,
Shall check occasion, as one doth his slave,
When he forgets the limits of prescription.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Sister Bridget, pray you fetch down the rose-water above in&H4; the closet. Sweet heart, will&H1; you come in&H5;, to&H4; breakfast.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: If she have overheard me now?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: I pray thee (good Musse) we&Htp; stay for&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: By&H4; heaven I would not for&H4; a thousand angels.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: What ail you sweet heart, are you not well, speak good Musse.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Troth my head aches extremely, on&H4; a sudden.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: O, the lord!

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: How now? what?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Alas, how it burns? Musse, keep you warm, good truth it is this new disease! there is a number are troubled withal! for&H4; loves sake, sweet heart, come in&H5;, out of the air.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: How simple, and how subtle are her&H2; answers?
A new disease, and many troubled with it!
Why, true: she heard me, all the world to&H4; nothing.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: [50] I pray thee, good sweetheart, come in&H5;; the air will&H1; do you harm in&H5;, troth.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: The air! she has me in&H4; the wind! sweet heart!
I will&H1; come to&H4; you presently: it will&H1; away, I hope.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Pray heaven it do.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: A new disease? I know not, new, or old,
But it may well be called poor mortals plague:
For&H3;, like&H4; a pestilence, it doth infect
The houses of the brain. First, it begins
Solely to&H9; work upon&H4; the fantasy,
Filling her&H2; seat with such pestiferous air,
As soon corrupts the judgment; and from thence,
Sends like&H4; contagion to&H4; the memory:
Still each to&H4; other giving the infection.
Which&H61;, as a subtle vapour, spreads itself,
Confusedly, through every sensive part,
Till not a thought, or motion, in&H4; the mind,
Be free from the black poison of suspect.
Ah, but what misery is it, to&H9; know this?
Or, knowing it, to&H9; want the minds erection,
In&H4; such extremes? Well, I will&H1; once more strive,
(In&H4; spite of this black cloud) myself to&H9; be,
And shake the fever off, that&H61; thus shakes me.

div2.stage:
Act II. Scene IIII.
Brayne-worme, Ed. Kno'well, M r. Stephen.

sp.p: 'slid, I cannot choose but laugh, to&H9; see myself translated thus, from a poor creature to&H4; a creator; for&H3; now must I create an intolerable sort of lies, or my present profession looses the grace: and yet the lie to&H4; a man of my coat, is as ominous a fruit, as the Fig. O sir, it holds for&H4; good polity ever, to&H9; have that&H62; outwardly in&H4; vilest estimation, that&H61; inwardly is most dear to&H4; us&Htp;. So&H51; much, for&H4; my borrowed shape. Well, the troth is, my old master intends to&H9; follow my young, dry foot, over More-fields, to&H4; London, this morning: now I, knowing, of this hunting-match, or rather conspiracy, and to&H9; insinuate with my young master (for&H3; so&H52; must we&Htp; that&H61; are blue-waiters, and men of hope and service do, or perhaps we&Htp; may wear motley at the years end, and who&H61; wears motley, you know) have got me afore, in&H4; this disguise, determining here to&H9; lie in&H4; ambuscado, and intercept him, in&H4; the mid-way. If I can but get his cloak, his purse, his hat, nay, anything, to&H9; cut him off, that&H62; is, to&H9; stay his journey, Veni, vidi, vici, I may say with Captain Caesar, I am made for&H4; ever, i'faith. Well, now must I practice to&H9; get the true garb of one of these Lance-knights, my arm here, and my---yong master! and his cousin, M r. Stephen, as I am true counterfeit man of war, and no&H2; soldier!

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: So&H52; sir, and how then, cuz?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, I have lost my purse, I think.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How? lost your purse? where? when had you it?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I cannot tell, stay.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: 'Slid, I am afeared, they will&H1; know me, would I could get by&H4; them.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: [25] What? have you it?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: No&H7;, I think I was bewitched, I---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, do not weep the loss, hang it, let it go.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O, it is here: no&H7;, if it had been lost, I had not cared, but for&H4; a jet ring mistress Marry sent me.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: A jet ring? O, the poesy, the poesy?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Fine, i'faith! Though fancy sleep, my love is deep. Meaning that&H3; though I did not fancy her&H6;, yet she loved me dearly.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Most excellent!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: And then, I sent her&H6; another, and my poesy was: The deeper, the sweeter, I will&H1; be judged by&H4; S t. Peter.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How, by&H4; S t. Peter? I do not conceive that&H62;!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Marry, S t. Peter, to&H9; make up&H5; the meeter.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Well, there the Saint was your good patron, he helped you at your need: thank him, thank him.

div2.stage: He is come back.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I cannot take leave on&H4; them, so&H52;: I will&H1; venture, come what will&H1;. Gentlemen, please you change a few crowns, for&H4; a very excellent good blade, here? I am a poor gentleman, a soldier, one that&H61; (in&H4; the better state of my fortunes) scorned so&H51; mean a refuge, but now it is the humour of necessity, to&H9; have it so&H52;. You seem to&H9; be gentlemen, well affected to&H4; martial men, else I should rather die with silence, than live with shame: how ever, vouchsafe to&H9; remember, it is my want speaks not myself. This condition agrees not with my spirit---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Where hast thou served?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: May it please you, sir, in&H4; all the late wars of Bohemia, Hungaria, [50] Dalmatia, Poland, where not, sir? I have been a poor servitor, by&H4; sea and land, any time this fourteen years, and followed the fortunes of the best Commanders in&H4; christendom. I was twice shot at the taking of Aleppo, once at the relief of Vienna; I have been at Marseilles, Naples, and the Adriatic gulf, a gentleman-slave in&H4; the galleys, thrice, where I was most dangerously shot in&H4; the head, through both the thighs, and yet, being thus maimed, I am void of maintenance, nothing left me but my scars, the noted marks of my resolution.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: How will&H1; you sell this rapier, friend?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Generous sir, I refer it to&H4; your own judgment; you are a gentleman, give me what you please.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: True, I am a gentleman, I know that&H62; friend: but what though? I pray you say, what would you ask?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I assure you, the blade may become the side, or thigh of the best prince, in&H4; Europe.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Aye, with a velvet scabbard, I think.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, if it be mine, it shall have a velvet scabbard, Cuz, that&H62; is flat: I would not wear it as it is, if you would give me an angel.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: At your worships pleasure, sir; nay, it is a most pure Toledo.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I had rather it were a Spaniard! but tell me, what shall I give you for&H4; it? If it had a silver hilt---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall not buy it; hold, there is a shilling fellow, take thy rapier.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, but I will&H1; buy it now, because you say so&H52;, and there is another shilling, fellow. I scorn to&H9; be out-bidden. What, shall I walk [75] with a cudgel, like&H4; Higgin-Bottom? and may have a rapier, for&H4; money?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: You may buy one in&H4; the city.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Tut, I will&H1; buy this in&H4; the field, so&H52; I will, I have a mind to&H4; it, because it is a field rapier. Tell me your lowest price.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: You shall not buy it, I say.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: By&H4; this money, but I will&H1;, though I give more than it is worth.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Come away, you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Friend, I am a fool, that&H62; is granted: but I will&H1; have it, for&H4; that&H62; words sake. Follow me, for&H4; your money.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: At your service, sir.

div2.stage:
Act II. Scene V.
Kno'well, Brayne-worme.

sp.l: I cannot loose the thought, yet, of this letter,
Sent to&H4; my son: nor leave to&H9; admire the change
Of manners, and the breeding of our&Htp; youth,
Within the kingdom, since mysekf was one.
When I was young, he lived not in&H4; the stews,
Durst have conceived a scorn, and uttered it,
On&H4; a grey head; age was authority
Against a buffoon: and a man had, then,
A certain reverence paid unto his years,
That&H61; had none due unto his life. So&H51; much
The sanctity of some prevailed, for&H4; others.
But, now, we&Htp; all are fallen; youth, from their fear:
And age, from that&H62;, which&H61; bred it, good example.
Nay, would ourselves were not the first, even parents,
That&H61; did destroy the hopes, in&H4; our&Htp; own children:
Or they not learned our&Htp; vices, in&H4; their cradles,
And sucked in&H5; our&Htp; ill customs, with their milk.
Ere all their teeth be born, or they can speak,
We&Htp; make their palates cunning! The first words,
We&Htp; form their tongues with, are licentious jests!
Can it call, whore? cry, bastard? O, then, kiss it,
A witty child! Cannot swear? The fathers darling!
Give it two plums. Nay, rather then it shall learn
No&H2; bawdy song, the mother herself will&H1; teach it!
[25] But, this is in&H4; the infancy; the days
Of the long coat: when it puts on&H5; the breeches,
It will&H1; put off all this. Aye, it is like&H5;:
When it is gone into the bone already.
No&H7;, no&H7;: This die goes deeper than the coat,
Or shirt, or skin. It stains, unto the liver,
And heart, in&H4; some. And, rather, than it should not,
Note, what we&Htp; fathers do! Look, how we&Htp; live!
What mistresses we&Htp; keep! at what expense,
In&H4; our&Htp; sons eyes! where they may handle our&Htp; gifts,
Hear our&Htp; lascivious courtships, see our&Htp; dalliance,
Taste of the same provoking meats, with us&Htp;,
To&H4; ruin of our&Htp; states! Nay, when our&Htp; own
Portion is fled, to&H9; prey on&H4; their remainder,
We&Htp; call them into fellowship of vice!
Bait them with the young chamber-maid, to&H9; seal!
And teach them all bad ways, to&H9; buy affection!
This is one path! but there are millions more,
In&H4; which&H61; we&Htp; spoil our&Htp; own, with leading them.
Well, I thank heaven, I never yet was he,
That&H61; travailed with my son, before sixteen,
To&H9; show him, the Venetian courtesans.
Nor read the grammar of cheating, I had made
To&H4; my sharpe boy, at twelve: repeating still
The rule, Get money; still, Get money, Boy;
[50] No&H2; matter, by&H4; what means; Money will&H1; do
More, Boy, than my Lords letter. Neither have I
Dressed snails, or mushrooms curiously before him,
Perfumed my sauces, and taught him to&H9; make them;
Preceding still, with my grey gluttony,
At all the ordinaries: and only feared
His palate should degenerate, not his manners.
These are the trade of fathers, now! how ever
My son, I hope, hath met within my threshold,
None of these household precedents; which&H61; are strong,
And swift, to&H9; rape youth, to&H4; their precipice.
But, let the house at home be never so&H51; clean-Swept,
or kept sweet from filth; nay, dust, and cob-webs:
If he will&H1; live, abroad, with his companions,
In&H4; dung, and lay-stalls; it is worth a fear.
Nor is the danger of conversing less,
Than all that&H61; I have mentioned of example.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: My master? nay, faith have at you: I am fleshed now, I have sped so&H51; well. Worshipful sir, I beseech you, respect the estate of a poor soldier; I am ashamed of this base course of life (god is my comfort) but extremity provokes me to&H4; it, what remedy?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: I have not for&H4; you, now.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: By&H4; the faith I bear unto truth, gentleman, it is no&H2; ordinary custom in&H4; me, but only to&H9; preserve manhood. I protest to&H4; you, a man I have been, a man I may be, by&H4; your sweet bounty.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: [75] Pray thee, good friend, be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Good sir, by&H4; that&H62; hand, you may do the part of a kind gentleman, in&H4; lending a poor soldier the price of two cannes of beer (a matter of small value) the king of heaven shall pay you, and I shall rest thankful: sweet worship---

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Nay, if you be so&H51; importunate---

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, tender sir, need will&H1; have his course: I was not made to&H4; this vile use! well, the edge of the enemy could not have abated me so&H51; Hee weepes. much: It is hard when a man hath served in&H4; his Princes cause, and be thus--- Honourable worship, let me derive a small piece of silver from you, it shall not be given in&H4; the course of time, by&H4; this good ground, I was fain to&H9; pawn my rapier last night for&H4; a poor supper, I had sucked the hilts long before, I am a pagan else: sweet honour.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Believe me, I am taken with some wonder,
To&H9; think, a fellow of thy outward presence
Should (in&H4; the frame, and fashion of his mind)
Be so&H51; degenerate, and sordid-base!
Art thou a man? and shamest thou not to&H9; beg?
To&H9; practise such a servile kind of life?
Why, were thy education never so&H51; mean,
Having thy limbs, a thousand fairer courses
Offer themselves, to&H4; thy election.
Either the wars might still supply thy wants,
Or service of some virtuous gentleman,
Or honest labour: nay, what can I name,
[100] But would become thee better than to&H9; beg?
But men of thy condition feed on&H4; sloth,
As doth the beetle, on&H4; the dung she breeds in&H5;,
Not caring how the metal of your minds
Is eaten with the rust of idleness.
Now, afore me, what ever he be, that&H61; should
Relieve a person of thy quality,
While thou insistest in&H4; this loose desperate course,
I would esteem the sin, not thine, but his.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith sir, I would gladly find some other course, if so&H52;---

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Aye, you would gladly find it, but you will&H1; not seek it.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Alas sir, where should a man seek? in&H4; the wars, there is no&H2; ascent by&H4; desert in&H4; these days, but---and for&H4; service, would it were as soon purchased, as wished for&H5; (the air is my comfort) I know, what I would say---

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Please, Fitz-Sword, sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Fitz-Sword?
Say, that&H3; a man should entertain thee now,
Wouldst thou be honest, humble, just, and true?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, by&H4; the place, and honour of a souldier---

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I like&H1; not those affected oaths;
Speak plainly man: what thinkst thou of my words?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nothing, sir, but wish my fortunes were as happy, as my service should be honest.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: [125] Well, follow me, I will&H1; prove thee, if thy deeds
Will&H1; carry a proportion to&H4; thy words.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Yes sir, straight, I will&H1; but garter my hose. O that&H3; my belly were hooped now, for&H3; I am ready to&H9; burst with laughing! never was bottle, or bag-pipe fuller. 'slid, was there ever seen a fox in&H4; years to&H9; betray himself thus? now shall I be possessed of all his counsels: and, by&H4; that&H62; conduit, my young master. Well, he is resolved to&H9; prove my honesty; faith, and I am resolved to&H9; prove his patience: O I shall abuse him intolerably. This small piece of service, will&H1; bring him clean out of love with the soldier, for&H4; ever. He will&H1; never come within the sign of it, the sight of a cassock, or a musket-rest again. He will&H1; hate the musters at Mile-end for&H4; it, to&H4; his dying day. It is no&H2; matter, let the world think me a bad counterfeit, if I cannot give him the slip, at an instant: why, this is better than to&H9; have staid his journey! well, I will&H1; follow him: O, how I long to&H9; be employed.

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene I.
Matthew, Well-bred, Bobadill, Ed: Kno'well, Stephen.

sp.p: Yes faith, sir, we&Htp; were at your lodging to&H9; seek you, too.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O, I came not there tonight.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Your brother delivered us&Htp; as much.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Who&H62;? my brother Downe-right?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: He. M r. Well-bred, I know not in&H4; what kind you hold me, but let me say to&H4; you this: as sure as honour, I esteem it so&H51; much out of the sunshine of reputation, to&H4; through the least beam of regard, upon&H4; such a---

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir, I must hear no&H2; ill words of my brother.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I, protest to&H4; you, as I have a thing to&H9; be saved about me, I never saw any gentleman-like part---

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Good Captain, faces about, to&H4; some other discourse.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: With your leave, sir, if there were no&H2; more men living upon&H4; the face of the earth, I should not fancy him, by&H4; S. George.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Troth, nor I, he is of a rustical cut, I know not how: he doth not carry himself like&H4; a gentleman of fashion---

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O, M r. Matthew, that&H62; is a grace peculiar but to&H4; a few; quos aquus amauit Ivpiter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I understand you sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No&H2; question, you do, or you do not, sir. Ned Kno'well! Yong Kno'well enters. by&H4; my soul welcome; how doest thou sweet spirit, my Genius? 'slid I shall love Apollo, and the mad Thespian girls the better, while I live, for&H4; this; my dear fury: now, I see there is some love in&H4; thee! Sirrah, these be the two I writ to&H4; thee of (nay, what a drowsy humour is this now? [25] why doest thou not speak?)

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, you are a fine gallant, you sent me a rare letter!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, was it not rare?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Yes, I will&H1; be sworn, I was never guilty of reading the like&H0;; match it in&H4; all Pliny, or Symmachvs epistles, and I will&H1; have my judgment burned in&H4; the ear for&H4; a rogue: make much of thy vain, for&H3; it is inimitable. But I marvel what camel it was, that&H61; had the carriage of it? for&H3; doubtless, he was no&H2; ordinary beast, that&H61; brought it!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Why, sayst thou? why doest thou think that&H3; any reasonable creature, especially in&H4; the morning (the sober time of the day too) could have mis-taken my father for&H4; me?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'slid, you jest, I hope?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Indeed, the best use we&Htp; can turn it to&H5;, is to&H9; make a jest of it, now: but I will&H1; assure you, my father had the full view of your flourishing style, some hour before I saw it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What a dull slave was this? But, sirrah, what said he to&H4; it, I'faith?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, I know not what he said: but I have a shrewd guess what he thought.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What? what?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Marry, that&H3; thou art some strange dissolute young fellow, and I a grain or two better, for&H4; keeping thee company.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Tut, that&H62; thought is like&H4; the moon in&H4; her&H2; last quarter, it will&H1; change shortly: but, sirrah, I pray thee be acquainted with my two hang-by's, [50] here; thou wilt take exceeding pleasure in&H4; them if thou hearest them once go: my wind-instruments. I will&H1; wind them up&H5;---but what strange piece of silence is this? the sign of the dumb man?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, sir, a kinsman of mine, one that&H61; may make your music the fuller, if he please, he has his humour, sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O, what is it? what is it?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, I will&H1; neither do your judgment, nor his folly that&H62; wrong, as to&H9; prepare your apprehension: I will&H1; leave him to&H4; the mercy of your search, if you can take him, so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well, Captain Bobadill, M r. Matthew, pray you know this gentleman here, he is a friend of mine, and one that&H61; will&H1; deserve your To Master Stephen. affection. I know not your name sir, but I shall be glad of any occasion, to&H9; render me more familiar to&H4; you

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: My name is M r. Stephen, sir, I am this gentleman's own cousin, sir, his father is mine uncle, sir, I am somewhat melancholy, but you shall command me, sir, in&H4; whatsoever is incident to&H4; a gentleman.

div2.stage: To Kno'well.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir, I must tell you this, I am no&H2; general man, but for&H4; M r. Welbred's sake (you may embrace it, at what height of favour you please) I do communicate with you: and conceive you, to&H9; be a gentleman of some parts, I love few words.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: And I fewer, sir. I have scarce enough, to&H9; thank you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: But are you indeed. Sir? so&H52; given to&H4; it?

div2.stage: To Master Stephen.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Aye, truly, sir, I am mightily given to&H4; melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, it is your only fine humour, sir, your true melancholy, breeds your perfect fine wit, sir: I am melancholy myself divers times, [75] sir, and then do I no&H2; more but take pen, and paper presently, and overflow you half a score, or a dozen of sonnets, at a sitting.

sp.speaker: (E. Kn.
sp.p: Sure, he utters them then, by&H4; the gross.)

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Truly sir, and I love such things, out of measure.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: I'faith, better than in&H4; measure, I will&H1; undertake.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why, I pray you, sir, make use of my study, it is at your service.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I thank you sir, I shall be bold, I warrant you; have you a stool there, to&H9; be melancholy upon&H5;?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That&H62; I have, sir, and some papers there of mine own doing, at idle hours, that&H3; you will&H1; say there is some sparks of wit in&H4; them, when you see them.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Would the sparks would kindle once, and become a fire amongst them, I might see self-love burned for&H4; her&H2; heresy.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Cousin, is it well? am I melancholy enough?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O Aye, excellent!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Captain Bobadill: why muse you so&H52;?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: He is melancholy, too.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Faith, sir, I was thinking of a most honourable piece of service, was performed tomorrow, being S t. Marks day: shall be some ten years, now?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: In&H4; what place, Captain?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why, at the beleaguering of Strigonium, where, in&H4; less than two hours, seven hundred resolute gentlemen, as any were in&H4; Europe, lost their lives upon&H4; the breach. I will&H1; tell you, gentlemen, it was the first, but the best leaguer, that&H61; ever I beheld, with these eyes, except the taking in&H5; of--- what [100] do you call it, last year, by&H4; the Genowayes, but that&H62; (of all other) was the most fatal, and dangerous exploit, that&H61; ever I was ranged in&H5;, since I first bore arms before the face of the enemy, as I am a gentleman, & soldier.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: So&H3;, I had as lief, as an angel, I could swear as well as that&H62; gentleman!

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Then, you were a servitor, at both it seems! at Strigonium? and what do you call it?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: O lord, sir? by&H4; S. George, I was the first man, that&H61; entered the breach: and, had I not effected it with resolution, I had been slain, if I had had a million of lives.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: It was pity, you had not ten; a cats, and your own, i'faith. But, was it possible?

sp.speaker: (Mat.
sp.p: Pray you, mark this discourse, sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: So&H52;, I do.)

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I assure you (upon&H4; my reputation) it is true, and yourself shall confess.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: You must bring me to&H4; the rack, first.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Observe me judicially, sweet sir, they had planted me three demi-culverings, just in&H4; the mouth of the breach; now, sir (as we&Htp; were to&H9; give on&H5;) their master gunner (a man of no&H2; mean skill, and mark, you must think) confronts me with his linstock, ready to&H9; give fire; I spying his intendment, discharged my petronel in&H4; his bosom, and with these single arms, my poor rapier, ran violently, upon&H4; the Moors, that&H61; guarded the ordinance, and put them pell-mell to&H4; the sword.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To&H4; the sword? to&H4; the rapier, Captain?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: [125] O, it was a good figure observed, sir! but did you all this, Captain, without hurting your blade.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Without any impeach, of the earth: you shall perceive sir. It is the most fortunate weapon, that&H61; ever rid on&H4; poor gentleman's thigh: shall I tell you, sir? you talk of Morglay, Excalibur, Durindana, or so&H52;? tut, I lend no&H2; credit to&H4; that&H62; is fabled of them, I know the virtue of mine own, and therefore I dare, the boldlier, maintain it.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I marvel whether it be a Toledo, or no&H5;?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A most perfect Toledo, I assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I have a countryman of his, here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pray you, let us&Htp; see, sir: yes faith, it is!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: This a Toledo? pish.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why do you pish, Captain?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A Fleming, by&H4; heaven, I will&H1; buy them for&H4; a guilder, a piece, and I would have a thousand of them.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How say you, cousin? I told you thus much?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where bought you it, M r. Stephen?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Of a scurvy rogue soldier (a hundred of lice go with him) he swore it was a Toledo.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A poor provant rapier, no&H2; better.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Mass, I think it be, indeed! now I look on&H4; it, better.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, the longer you look on&H4; it, the worse. Put it up&H5;, put it up&H5;.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Well, I will&H1; put it up&H5;, but by&H4;---(I have forgot the Captains oath, I thought to&H9; have sworn by&H4; it) if ere I meet him---

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: [150] O, it is past help now, sir, you must have patience.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Whoreson cony catching rascal! I could eat the very hilts for&H4; anger!

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: A sign of good digestion! you have an ostrich stomach, cousin.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: A stomach? would I had him here, you should see, if I had a stomach.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is better as it is: come, gentlemen, shall we&Htp; go?

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene II.
E. Kno'well, Brayne-worme, Stephen, Well-bred, Bobadill, Matthew.

sp.p: A miracle, cousin, look here! look here!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O, gods lid, by&H4; your leave, do you know me, sir?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Aye sir, I know you, by&H4; sight.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: You sold me a rapier, did you not?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Yes, marry, did I sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: You said, it was a Toledo, ha?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: True, I did so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: But, it is none?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No&H7; sir, I confess it, it is none.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Do you confess it? gentlemen, bear witness, he has confessed it. By&H4; gods will&H0;, if you had not confessed it---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O cousin, forbear, forbear.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, I have done, cousin.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why you have done like&H4; a gentleman, he has confessed it, what would you more?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Yet, by&H4; his leave, he is a rascal, under his favour, do you see?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Aye, by&H4; his leave, he is, and under favour: a pretty piece of civility! Sirrah, how doest thou like&H1; him?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O, it is a most precious fool, make much on&H4; him: I can compare him to&H4; nothing more happily, than a drum; for&H3; every one may play upon&H4; him.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: No&H7;, no&H7;, a childes whistle were far the fitter.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, shall I entreat a word with you?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: With me, sir? you have not another Toledo to&H9; sell, have you?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: [25] You are conceited, sir, your name is Mr. Kno'well, as I take it?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: You are, in&H4; the right? you mean not to&H9; proceed in&H4; the catechism, do you?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No&H7; sir, I am none of that&H62; coat.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Of as bare a coat, though? well, say sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith sir, I am but servant to&H4; the drum extraordinary, and indeed (this smoky varnish being washed off, and three or four patches removed) I appear your worships in&H4; reversion, after the decease of your good father, Brayne-worme.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Brayne-worme! 'slight, what breath of a conjurer, hath blown thee hither in&H4; this shape.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: The breath of your letter, sir, this morning: the same that&H61; blew you to&H4; the wind-mill, and your father after you.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: My father?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nay, never start, it is true, he has followed you over the field's, by&H4; the foot, as you would do a hare in&H4; the snow.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Sirrah, Wel-bred, what shall we&Htp; do, sirrah? my father is come over, after me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Thy father? where is he?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: At Justice Clements house here, in&H4; Colman street, where he but stays my return; and then---

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Who&H62; is this? Brayne-worme?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: The same, sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why how, in&H4; the name of wit, comest thou transmuted, thus?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: [50] Faith, a devise, a devise: nay, for&H4; the love of reason, gentlemen, and avoiding the danger, stand not here, withdraw, and I will&H1; tell you all.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But, art thou sure, he will&H1; stay thy return?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Do I live, sir? what a question is that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: We&Htp; will&H1; prorogue his expectation then, a little: Brayne-worme, thou shalt go with us&Htp;. Come on&H5;, gentlemen, nay, I pray thee, sweet Ned, droop not: 'sheart, if our&Htp; wits be so&H51; wretchedly dull, that&H3; one old plodding brain can out-strip us&Htp; all, would we&Htp; were even pressed, to&H9; make porters of; and serve out the remnant of our&Htp; days, in&H4; Thames-street, or at Custom-house key, in&H4; a civil war, against the car-men.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Amen, Amen, Amen, say I.

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene III.
Kitely, Cash.

sp.l: What says he, Thomas? Did you speak with him?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: He will&H1; expect you, sir, within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Has he the money ready, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Yes, sir, the money was brought in&H5;, last night.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: O, that&H62; is well: fetch me my cloak, my cloak.
Stay, let me see, an hour, to&H9; go and come;
Aye, that&H62; will&H1; be the least: and then it will&H1; be
An hour, before I can dispatch with him;
Or very near: well, I will&H1; say two hours.
Two hours? ha? things, never dreamt of yet,
May be contrived, Aye, and effected too,
In&H4; two hours absence: well, I will&H1; not go.
Two hours; no&H7;, fleering opportunity,
I will&H1; not give your subtlety that&H62; scope.
Who&H62; will&H1; not judge him worthy to&H9; be robbed,
That&H61; sets his doors wide open to&H4; a thief,
And shows the felon, where his treasure lies?
Again, what earthy spirit but will&H1; attempt
To&H4; the taste fruit of beauties golden tree,
When leaden sleep seals up&H5; the Dragons eyes?
I will&H1; not go. Business, go by&H5;, for&H4; once.
No&H7; beauty, no&H7;; you are of too good character,
To&H9; be left so&H52;, without a guard, or open!
Your lustre too will&H1; inflame, at any distance,
[25] Draw courtship to&H4; you, as a jet doth straws,
Put motion in&H4; a stone, strike fire from ice,
Nay, make a porter leap you, with his burden!
You must be then kept up&H5;, close, and well-watched,
For&H3;, give you opportunity, no&H2; quick-sand
Devours, or swallows swifter! He that&H61; lends
His wife (if she be fair) or time, or place;
Compels her&H6; to&H9; be false. I will&H1; not go.
The dangers are too many. And, then, the dressing
Is a most main attractive! Our&Htp; great heads,
Within the city, never were in&H4; safety,
Since our&Htp; wives wore these little caps: I will&H1; change them,
I will&H1; change them, straight, in&H4; mine. Mine shall no&H2; more
Wear three piled acorns, to&H9; make my horns ache.
Nor, will&H1; I go. I am resolved for&H4; that&H62;.
Carry in&H5; my cloak again. Yet, stay. Yet, do too.
I will&H1; defer going, on&H4; all occasions.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Sir. Snare, your scrivener, will&H1; be there with the bonds.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: That&H62; is true! fool on&H4; me! I had clean forgot it,
I must go. What is clock?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Exchange time, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: 'sheart, then will&H1; Well-bred presently be here, too,
With one, or other of his loose consorts.
I am a knave, if I know what to&H9; say,
