What course to&H9; take, or which&H61; way to&H9; resolve.
[50] My brain (methinks) is like&H4; an hourglass,
Wherein, my imaginations run, like&H4; sands,
Filling up&H5; time; but then are turned, and turned:
So&H3;, that&H3; I know not what to&H9; stay upon&H5;,
And less, to&H9; put in&H4; act. It shall be so&H52;.
Nay, I dare build upon&H4; his secrecy,
He knows not to&H9; deceive me. Thomas?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Yet now, I have bethought me, too, I will&H1; not.
Thomas, is Cob within?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: I think he be, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: But he will&H1; prate too, there is no&H2; speech of him.
No&H7;, there were no&H2; man on&H4; the earth to&H4; Thomas,
If I durst trust him; there is all the doubt.
But, should he have a chink in&H4; him, I were gone,
Lost in&H4; my fame for&H4; ever: talk for&H4; the exchange.
The manner he hath stood with, till this present,
Doth promise no&H2; such change! what should I fear then?
Well, come what will&H1;, I will&H1; tempt my fortune, once.
Thomas ---you may deceive me, but, I hope---
Your love, to&H4; me, is more---

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir, if a servants Duty, with faith, may be called love, you are More than in&H4; hope, you are possessed of it.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I thank you, heartily, Thomas; Give me your hand:
[75] With all my heart, good Thomas. I have, Thomas,
A secret to&H9; impart, unto you---but
When once you have it, I must seal your lips up&H5;:
(So&H51; far, I tell you, Thomas.)

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir, for&H4; that&H62;---

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Nay, hear me, out. Think, I esteem you, Thomas,
When, I will&H1; let you in&H5;, thus, to&H4; my private.
It is a thing sits, nearer, to&H4; my crest,
Than thou art ware of, Thomas. If thou shouldest
Reveal it, but---

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: How? I reveal it?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Nay,
I do not think thou wouldst; but if thou shouldest:
It were a great weakness.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: A great treachery. Give it no&H2; other name.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Thou wilt not do it, then?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir, if I do, mankind disclaim me, ever.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: He will&H1; not swear, he has some reservation,
Some concealed purpose, and close meaning, sure:
Else (being urged so&H51; much) how should he choose,
But lend an oath to&H4; all this protestation?
He is no&H2; precisian, that&H62; I am certain of.
Nor rigid Roman-Catholic. He will&H1; play,
At Fayles, and Tick-tack, I have heard him swear.
[100] What should I think of it? urge him again,
And by&H4; some other way? I will&H1; do so&H52;.
Well, Thomas, thou hast sworn not to&H9; disclose;
Yes, you did swear?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Not yet, sir, but I will&H1;, Please you---

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: No&H7;, Thomas, I dare take thy word.
But; if thou wilt swear, do, as thou thinkst good;
I am resolved without it; at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: By&H4; my souls safety then, sir, I protest.
My tongue shall never take knowledge of a word,
Delivered me in&H4; nature of your trust.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: It is too much, these ceremonies need not,
I know thy faith to&H9; be as firm as rock.
Thomas, come hither, near: we&Htp; cannot be
Too private, in&H4; this business. So&H52; it is,
(Now, he has sworn, I dare the safelier venture)
I have of late, by&H4; divers obseruations---
(But, whether his oath can bind him, yea, or no&H5;,
Being not taken lawfully? ha? say you?
I will&H1; ask counsel, ere I do proceed:)
Thomas, it will&H1; be now too long to&H9; stay,
I will&H1; spy some fitter time soon, or tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir, at your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I will&H1; think. And, Thomas,
[125] I pray you search the books against my return,
For&H4; the receipts betwixt me, and Traps.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I will&H1;, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: And, hear you, if your mistress brother, Wel-bred,
Chance to&H9; bring hither any gentlemen,
Ere I come back; let one straight bring me word.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: To&H4; the Exchange; do you hear?
Or thee in&H4; Colman-street, to&H4; Justice Clements.
Forget it not, nor be not out of the way.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I will&H1; not, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I pray you have a care on&H4; it.
Or whether he come, or no&H5;, if any other,
Stranger, or else, fail not to&H9; send me word.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I shall not, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Be it your special business
Now, to&H9; remember it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir. I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: But, Thomas, this is not the secret, Thomas,
I told you of.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: No&H7;, sir. I do suppose it.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Believe me, it is not.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir. I do believe you.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: By&H4; heaven, it is not, that&H62; is enough. But, Thomas,
I would not, you should utter it, do you see?
[150] To&H4; any creature living, yet, I care not.
Well, I must hence. Thomas, conceive thus much.
It was a trial of you, when I meant
So&H51; deep a secret to&H4; you, I mean not this,
But that&H3; I have to&H9; tell you, this is nothing, this.
But, Thomas, keep this from my wife, I charge you,
Locked up&H5; in&H4; silence, mid-night, buried here.
No&H2; greater hell, than to&H9; be slave to&H4; fear.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Locked up&H5; in&H4; silence, mid-night, buried here.
Whence should this flood of passion (trow) take head? ha?
Best, dream no&H2; longer of this running humour,
For&H4; fear I sink! the violence of the stream
Already hath transported me so&H51; far,
That&H3; I can feele no&H2; ground at all! but soft,
O, it is our&Htp; water-bearer: somewhat has crossed him, now.

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene IIII.
Cob, Cash.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Why, how now Cob, what moves thee to&H4; this choler? ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Collar, master Thomas? I scorn your collar, I sir, I am none of your cart-horse, though I carry, and draw water. If you offer to&H9; ride me, with your collar, or halter either, I may hap show you a jades trick, sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: O, you will&H1; slip your head out of the collar? why, goodman Cob, you mistake me.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, I have my rheum, & I can be angry as well as another, sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Thy rheum, Cob? thy humour, thy humour? thou mistakest.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Humour? mack, I think it be so&H52;, indeed: what is that&H62; humour? some rare thing, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Marry, I will&H1; tell thee, Cob : It is a gentleman-like monster, bred, in&H4; the special gallantry of our&Htp; time, by&H4; affectation; and fed by&H4; folly.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How? must it be fed?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: O Aye, humour is nothing, if it be not fed. Didst thou never hear that&H62;? it is a common phrase, Feed my humour.

sp.speaker: Cob.
Cas.
sp.p: I pray thee, good Cob, what makes thee so&H51; out of love with fasting-days?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry that&H62;, which&H61; will&H1; make any man out of love with them, I think: their bad conditions, and you will&H1; needs know. First, they are of a Flemish breed, I am sure of it, for&H3; they raven up&H5; more butter, than all the days of the week, beside; next, they stink of fish, and leek-porridge miserably: thirdly, they will&H1; keep a man devoutly hungry, all day, and at night send him supperless to&H4; bed.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Indeed, these are faults, Cob.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, if this were all, it were something, but they are the only known enemies, to&H4; my generation. A fasting-day, no&H2; sooner comes, but my lineage goes to&H4; rack, poor cobs they smoke for&H4; it, they are made martyrs of the gridiron, they melt in&H4; passion: and your maids too know this, and yet would have me turn Hannibal, and eat my own fish, He pulls out a red herring. and blood: My princely cuz, fear nothing; I have not the heart to&H9; devour you, & I might be made as rich as King Cophetva. O, that&H3; I had room for&H4; my tears, I could weep salt-water enough, now, to&H9; preserve the lives of ten thousand of my kin. But, I may curse none but these filthy Almanacs, for&H3; if it were not for&H4; them, these days of persecution would never be known. I will&H1; be hanged, handsome Fish-mongers son do not make of hem; and puts in&H5; more fasting-days than he should do, because he would utter his fathers dried stock-fish, and stinking conger.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: 'slight, peace, thou wilt be beaten like&H4; a stock-fish, else: here is [50] M r. Matthew. Now must I look out for&H4; a messenger to&H4; my master.

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene V.
Well-bred, Ed. Kno'well, Brayne-worme, Bobadill, Matthew, Stephen, Thomas, Cob.

sp.p: Beshrew me, but it was an absolute good jest, and exceedingly well carried!

sp.speaker: E. Kno.
sp.p: Aye, and our&Htp; ignorance maintained it as well, did it not?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes faith, but was it possible thou shouldest not know him? I forgive M r. Stephen, for&H3; he is stupidity itself!

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Before god, not I, and I might have been joined patten with one of the seven wise masters, for&H4; knowing him. He had so&H51; writhen himself, into the habit of one of your poor Infantry, your decayed, ruinous, worm-eaten gentlemen of the round: such as have vowed to&H9; sit on&H4; the skirts of the city, let your Provost, and his half-dozen of halberdiers do what they can; and have translated begging out of the old hackney pace, to&H4; a fine easy amble, and made it run as smooth, of the tongue, as a shove groat shilling. Into the likeness of one of these Reformado's had he moulded himself so&H51; perfectly, observing every trick of their action, as varying the accent, swearing with an emphasis, indeed all, with so&H51; special, and exquisite a grace, that&H3; (hadst thou seen him) thou wouldst have sworn, he might have been Sergeant-Major, if not Lieutenant-Coronell to&H4; the regiment.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, Brayne-worme, who&H62; would have thought thou hadst been such an artificer?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: An artificer? An architect! except a man had studied begging all his life-time, and been a weaver of language, from his infancy, for&H4; the clothing of it! I never saw his rival.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where gottest thou this coat, I marvel?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: [25] Of a Hounds-ditch man, sir. One of the devil's near kinsmen, a broker.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: That&H62; cannot be, if the proverb hold; for&H3;, a crafty knave needs no&H2; broker.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: True sir, but I did need a broker, Ergo.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: (Well put off) no&H2; crafty knave, you will&H1; say.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Tut, he has more of these shifts.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: And yet where I have one, the broker has ten, sir,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Francis, Martin, never a one to&H9; be found, now? what a spite's this?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How now, Thomas? is my brother Kitely, within?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No&H7; sir, my master went forth even now: but master Downeright is within. Cob, what Cob? is he gone too?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Whither went your master? Thomas, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I know not, to&H4; Justice Clements, I think, sir. Cob.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Justice Clement, what is he?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, doest thou not know him? he is a city-magistrate, a Justice here, an excellent good Lawyer, and a great scholar: but the only mad, merry, old fellow in&H4; Europe! I showed him you, the other day.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, is that&H62; he? I remember him now. Good faith, and he has a very strange presence, methinks; it shows as if he stood out of the rank, from other men: I have heard many of his jests in&H4; university. They say, he will&H1; commit a man, for&H4; taking the wall, of his horse.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Aye, or wearing his cloak of one shoulder, or serving of god: anything indeed, if it come in&H4; the way of his humour.

div2.stage: Cash goes in and out calling.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: [50] Gasper, Martin, Cob: 'sheart, where should they be, trow?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Master Kitely's man, pray thee vouchsafe us&Htp; the lighting of this match.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Fire on&H4; your match, no&H2; time but now to&H9; vouchsafe? Francis. Cob.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Body of me! here is the remainder of seven pound, since yesterday was seven-night. It is your right Trinidado! did you never take any, master Stephen?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: No&H7; truly, sir? but I will&H1; learn to&H9; take it now, since you commend it, so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir, believe me (upon&H4; my relation) for&H4; what I tell you, the world shall not reprove. I have been in&H4; the Indies (where this herb grows) where neither myself, nor a dozen gentlemen more (of my knowledge) have received the taste of any other nutriment, in&H4; the world, for&H4; the space of one and twenty weeks, but the fume of this simple only. Therefore, it cannot be, but it is most divine! Further, take in&H5; the nature, in&H4; the true kind so&H52;, it makes an antidote, that&H3; (had you taken the most deadly poisonous plant in&H4; all Italy, it should expel it, and clarify you, with as much ease, as I speak. And, for&H4; your green wound, your Balsamum, and your S t. Iohn's wort are all mere gulleries, and trash to&H4; it, especially your Trinidado: your Nicotine is good too. I could say what I know of the virtue of it, for&H4; the expulsion of rheums, raw humours, crudities, obstructions, with a thousand of this kind; but I profess myself no&H2; quack-salver. Only, thus much, by&H4; Hercules, I do hold it, and will&H1; affirm it (before any Prince in&H4; Europe) to&H9; be the most sovereign, and precious weed, [75] that&H61; ever the earth tendered to&H4; the use of man.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: This speech would have done decently in&H4; a tobacco-traders mouth!

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: At Justice Clements, he is: in&H4; the middle of Colman-street.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, O?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Where is the match I gave thee? Master Kitelies man?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Would his match, and he, and pipe, and all were at Sancto Domingo! I had forgot it.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p:
By&H4; gods me, I marvel, what pleasure, or felicity they have in&H4; taking this roguish tobacco! it is good for&H4; nothing, but to&H9; choke a man, and fill him full of smoke, and embers: there were four died out of one
house, last week, with taking of it, and two more the bell went for&H5;, yesternight; one of them (they say) will&H1; never scape it: he voided a bushel of soot yesterday, upward, and downward. By&H4; the stocks, if there were no&H2; wiser men then I, I would have it present whipping, man, or woman, that&H61; should but deal with a tobacco pipe; why, it will&H1; stifle them all in&H4; the end, as many as use it; it is little better than rats bane, or realgar.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O, good Captain, hold, hold.

div2.stage: Bobadil beates him with a cudgell.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: You base cullion, you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir, here is your match: come, thou must needs be talking, too, thou art well enough served.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, he will&H1; not meddle with his match, I warrant you: well it shall be a dear beating, if I live.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Do you prate? Do you murmur?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, good Captain, will&H1; you regard the humour of a fool? away, knave.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: [100] Thomas, get him away.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A whoreson filthy slave, a dung-worm, an excrement! Body of Caesar, but that&H3; I scorn to&H9; let forth so&H51; mean a spirit, I would have stabbed him, to&H4; the earth.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Marry, the law-forbid, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: By&H4; Pharoahs foot, I would have done it.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O, he swears admirably! (by&H4; Pharoahs foot) (body of Caesar ) I shall never do it, sure (upon&H4; mine honour, and by&H4; Saint George) no&H7;, I have not the right grace.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Master Stephen, will&H1; you any? By&H4; this air, the most divine tobacco, that&H61; ever I drunk!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: None, I thank you, sir. O, this gentleman does it, rarely too! but nothing like&H4; the other. By&H4; this air, as I am a gentleman: by&H4;---

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master, glance, glance! Master Well-bred!

div2.stage: Master Stephen is practising, to the post.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: As I have somewhat to&H9; be saved, I protest---

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are a fool: It needs no&H2; affidavit.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Cousin, will&H1; you any tobacco?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Aye sir! upon&H4; my reputation---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How now, cousin!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I protest, as I am a gentleman, but no&H2; soldier, indeed---

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No&H7;, Master Stephen? as I remember your name is entered in&H4; the artillery garden?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Aye sir, that&H62; is true: Cousin, may I swear, as I am a soldier, by&H4; that&H62;?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O yes, that&H62; you may. It is all you have for&H4; your money.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Then, as I am a gentleman, and a soldier, it is divine tobacco!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: [125] But soft, where is M r. Matthew? gone?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No&H7;, sir, they went in&H5; here.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O, let us&Htp; follow them: master Matthew is gone to&H9; salute his mistress, in&H4; verse. We&Htp; shall have the happiness, to&H9; hear some of his poetry, now. He never comes unfurnished. Brayne-worme?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Brayne-worme? Where? Is this Brayne-worme?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Aye, cousin, no&H2; words of it, upon&H4; your gentility.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Not I, body of me, by&H4; this air, S. George, and the foot of Pharaoh.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Rare! your cousins discourse is simply drawn out with oaths.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: It is larded with them. A kind of french dressing, if you love it.

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene VI.
Kitely, Cob.

sp.l: Ha? how many are there, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry sir, your brother, master VVell-bred ---

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Tut, beside him: what strangers are there, man?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Strangers? let me see, one, two; mass I know not well, there are so&H51; many.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: How? so&H51; many?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Aye, there is some five, or six of them, at the most.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: A swarm, a swarm,
Spite of the devil, how they sting my head
With forked stings, thus wide, and large! But, Cob,
How long hast thou been coming hither, Cob?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: A little while, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Didst thou come running?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: No&H7;, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Nay, then I am familiar with thy haste!
Bane to&H4; my fortunes: what meant I to&H9; marry?
I, that&H61; before was ranked in&H4; such content,
My mind at rest too, in&H4; so&H51; soft a peace,
Being free master of mine own free thoughts,
And now become a slave? What? never sigh,
Be of good cheer, man: for&H3; thou art a cuckold,
It is done, it is done! nay, when such flowing store,
Plenty itself, falls in&H4; my wives lap,
The Cornucopiaæ will&H1; be mine, I know. But, Cob,
[25] What entertainment had they? I am sure
My sister, and my wife, would bid them welcome! ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Like&H5; enough, sir, yet, I heard not a word of it.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: No&H7;: their lips were sealed with kisses, and the voice
Drowned in&H4; a flood of joy, at their arrival,
Had lost her&H2; motion, state, and faculty.
Cob, which&H62; of them was it, that&H61; first kissed my wife?
(My sister, I should say) my wife, alas,
I fear not her&H6;: ha? who&H62; was it, sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: By&H4; my troth, sir, will&H1; you have the truth of it?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: O Aye, good Cob: I pray thee, heartily.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Then, I am a vagabond, and fitter for&H4; Bride-well, than your worships company, if I saw anybody to&H9; be kissed, unless they would have kissed the post, in&H4; the middle of the ware-house; for&H3; there I left them all, at their tobacco, with a pox.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: How? were they not gone in&H5;, then, ever thou camest?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O no&H7; sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Spite of the devil! what do I stay here, then? Cob, follow me.

sp.speaker: Cob.

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene VII.
Clement, Kno'well, Formall, Cob.

sp.p: What is master Kitely gone? Roger?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Aye, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: 'sheart of me! what made him leave us&Htp; so&H51; abruptly! How now, sirrah? what make you here? what would you have, ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: If it please your worship, I am a poor neighbour of your worships---

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A poor neighbour of mine? why, speak poor neighbour.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I dwell, sir, at the sign of the water-tankard, hard by&H4; the green lattice: I have paid scot, and lot there, any time this eighteen years.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: To&H4; the green lattice?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: No&H7;, sir, to&H4; the parish: marry, I have seldom scaped scot-free, at the lattice.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: O, well! what business has my poor neighbour with me?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: If it like&H1; your worship, I am come, to&H9; crave the peace of your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Of me knave? peace of me, knave? did I ever hurt thee? or threaten thee? or wrong thee? ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: No&H7;, sir, but your worships warrant, for&H4; one that&H61; has wronged me, sir: his arms are at too much liberty, I would fain have them bound to&H4; a treaty of peace, if my credit could compass it, with your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Thou goest far enough about for&H4; it, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Why, doest thou go in&H4; danger of thy life for&H4; him? friend?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: No&H7; sir; but I go in&H4; danger of my death, every hour, by&H4; his means: if I die, within a twelvemonth and a day, I may swear, by&H4; the [25] law of the land, that&H3; he killed me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How? how knave? swear he killed thee? and by&H4; the law? what pretence? what colour hast thou for&H4; that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry, if it please your worship, both black, and blue; colour enough, I warrant you. I have it here, to&H9; show your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What is he, that&H61; gave you this, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: A gentleman, and a soldier, he says he is, of the city here.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A soldier of the city? What call you him?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Captain Bobadil.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Bobadil? And why did he bob, and beat you, sirrah? How began the quarrel betwixt you? ha: speak truly knave, I advise you.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry, indeed, if it please your worship, only because I spake against their vagrant tobacco, as I came by&H4; them, when they were taking on&H4; it, for&H4; nothing else.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Ha? you speak against tobacco? Formall, his name.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: What is your name, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Oliver, sir, Oliver Cob, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Tell Oliver Cob, he shall go to&H4; the jail, Formall.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: Oliver Cob, my master, Justice Clement, says, you shall go to&H4; the jail.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, I beseech your worship, for&H4; gods sake, dear master Justice.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, gods precious: and such drunkards, and tankards, as you are, come to&H9; dispute of tobacco once; I have done! away with him.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, good master Justice, sweet old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Sweet Oliver, would I could do thee any good: Justice [50] Clement, let me entreat you, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What? a thread-bare rascal! a beggar! a slave that&H61; never drunk out of better than piss-pot mettle in&H4; his life! and he to&H9; deprave, and abuse the virtue of an herb, so&H51; generally received in&H4; the courts of princes, the chambers of nobles, the bowers of sweet ladies, the cabins of soldiers! Roger, away with him, by&H4; gods pretious---I say, go to&H5;.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Dear master Justice; Let me be beaten again, I have deserved it: but not the prison, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Alas, poor Oliver!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Roger, make him a warrant (he shall not go) I but fear the knave.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: Do not stink, sweet Oliver, you shall not go, my master will&H1; give you a warrant.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, the Lord maintain his worship, his worthy worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Away, dispatch him. How now, master Kno'wel! In&H4; dumps? In&H4; dumps? Come, this becomes not.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Sir, would I could not feele my cares---

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Your cares are nothing! they are like&H4; my cap, soon put on&H5;, and as soon put off. What? your son is old enough, to&H9; govern himself: let him run his course, it is the only way to&H9; make him a stayed man. If he were an unthrift, a ruffian, a drunkard, or a licentious liver, then you had reason; you had reason to&H9; take care: but, being none of these, mirth's my witness, if I had twice so&H51; many cares, as you have, I would drown them all in&H4; a cup of sack. Come, come, let us&Htp; try it: I muse, your parcel of a soldier returns not all this while.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene I.
Downe-right, Dame Kitely.

sp.p: Well sister, I tell you true: and you will&H1; find it so&H52;, in&H4; the end.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Alas brother, what would you have me to&H9; do? I cannot help it: you see, my brother brings them in&H5;, here, they are his friends.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: His friends? his fiends. 'slid, they do nothing but haunt him, up&H5; and down, like&H4; a sort of unlucky sprites, and tempt him to&H4; all manner of villainy, that&H61; can be thought of. Well, by&H4; this light, a little thing would make me play the devil with some of them; and it were not more for&H4; your husbands sake, than anything else, I would make the house too hot for&H4; the best of hem: they should say, and swear, hell were broken loose, ere they went hence. But, by&H4; gods will&H0;, it is nobody's fault, but yours: for&H3;, if you had done, as you might have done, they should have been parboiled, and baked too, every mothers son, ere they should have come in&H5;, ere a one of them.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: God is my life! did you ever hear the like&H0;? what a strange man is this! Could I keep out all them, think you? I should put myself, against half a dozen men? should I? Good faith, you would mad the patientest body in&H4; the world, to&H9; hear you talk so&H52;, without any sense, or reason!

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene II.
M r s. Bridget, M r. Matthew, Dame Kitely, Downe-right, Wel-bred, Stephen, Ed. Kno'well, Bobadil, Brayne-worme, Cash.

sp.l: Servant (in&H4; troth) you are too prodigal
Of your wits treasure, thus to&H9; pour it forth,
Upon&H4; so&H51; mean a subject, as my worth?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You say well, mistress; and I mean, as well.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Hoy-day, here is stuff!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, now stand close: pray heaven, she can get him to&H9; read: He should do it, of his own natural impudency.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Servant, what is this same, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Marry, an Elegy, an Elegy, an odd toy---

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: To&H9; mock an ape withal. O, I could sew up&H5; his mouth, now.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Sister, I pray you let us&Htp; hear it.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Are you rime-given, too?

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Mistress, I will&H1; read it, if you please.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Pray you do, servant.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: O, here is no&H2; foppery! Death, I can endure the stocks, better.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: What ails thy brother? can he not hold his water, at reading of a ballad?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, no&H7;: a rime to&H4; him, is worse than cheese, or a bag-pipe. But, mark, you loose the protestation.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Faith, I did it in&H4; an humour; I know not how it is: but, please you come near, sir. This gentleman has judgment, he knows how to&H9; censure of a---pray you sir, you can judge.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Not I, sir: upon&H4; my reputation, and, by&H4; the foot of Pharoah.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, chide your cousin, for&H4; swearing.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: [25] Not I, so&H51; long as he does not forswear himself.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Master Matthew, you abuse the expectation of your dear mistress, and her&H2; fair sister: Fie, while you live, avoid this prolixity.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: I shall, sir: well, Incipere dulce.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How! Insipere dulce? a sweet thing to&H9; be a fool, indeed.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What, do you take Insipere, in&H4; that&H62; sense?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: You do not? you? This was your villainy, to&H9; gull him with a motte.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, the Benchers phrase: pauca verba, pauca verba.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Rare creature, let me speak without offence,
Would god my rude words had the influence,
To&H9; rule thy thoughts, as thy fair looks do mine,
Then shouldest thou be his prisoner, who&H61; is thine.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: This is in&H4; Hero and Leander?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, Aye! peace, we&Htp; shall have more of this.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Be not unkind, and fair, misshapen stuff
Is of behaviour boisterous, and rough:

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: How like&H1; you that&H62;, sir?

div2.stage: Master Stephen answeres with shaking his head.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: 'slight, he shakes his head like&H4; a bottle, to&H9; feele if there be any brain in&H4; it!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: But observe the catastrophe, now,
And I in&H4; duty will&H1; exceed all other,
As you in&H4; beauty do excel loves mother.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Well, I will&H1; have him free of the wit-brokers, for&H3; he utters nothing, but stolen remnants.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: [50] O, forgive it him.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: A filching rogue? hang him. And, from the dead? it is worse than sacrilege.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sister, what have you here? verses? pray you, let us&Htp; see. Who&H62; made these verses? they are excellent good!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, master Wel-bred, it is your disposition to&H9; say so&H52;, sir. They were good in&H4; the morning, I made them, extempore, this morning.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How? extempore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Aye, would I might be hanged else: ask Captain Bobadill. He saw me write them, at the---(pox on&H4; it) the star, yonder.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Can he find, in&H4; his heart, to&H9; curse the stars, so&H52;?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Faith, his are even with him: they have cursed him enough already.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Cousin, how do you like&H1; this gentleman's verses?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, admirable! the best that&H61; ever I heard, cuz!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Body of Caesar! they are admirable! The best, that&H61; ever I heard, as I am a soldier.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: I am vext, I can hold never a bone of me still! Heart, I think, they mean to&H9; build, and breed here!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sister, you have a simple servant here, that&H61; crowns your beauty, with such encomions, and devises: you may see, what it is to&H9; be the mistress of a wit! that&H61; can make your perfections so&H51; transparent, that&H3; every blear eye may look through them, and see him drowned over head, and ears, in&H4; the deep well of desire. Sister Kitely, I marvel, you get you not a servant, that&H61; can rime, and do tricks, too.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: [75] O monster! impudence itself! tricks?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Tricks, brother? what tricks?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Nay, speak, I pray you, what tricks?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Aye, never spare anybody here: but say, what tricks?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Passion of my heart! do tricks?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'slight, here is a trick vied, and revied! why, you monkeys, you? what a cater-waling do you keep? has he not given you rimes, and verses, and tricks?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: O, the fiend!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, you, lamp of virginity, that&H61; take it in&H4; snuff so&H52;! come, and cherish this tame poetical fury, in&H4; your servant, you will&H1; be begged else, shortly, for&H4; a concealment: go to&H5;, reward his muse. You cannot give him less than a shilling, in&H4; conscience, for&H3; the book, he had it out of, cost him a teston, at least. How now, gallants? M r. Matthew? Captain? What? all sons of silence? no&H2; spirit?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Come, you might practise your ruffian-tricks somewhere else, and not here, I wuss: this is no&H2; tavern, nor drinking-school, to&H9; vent your exploits in&H5;.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How now! whose cow has calved?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Marry, that&H62; has mine, sir. Nay, Boy, never look askance at me, for&H4; the matter; I will&H1; tell you of it, Aye, sir, you, and companions, mend yourselves, when I have done?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My companions?

sp.speaker: Dow.
Wel.
sp.p: 'slight, stay, let us&Htp; see what he dare do: cut off his ears? cut a whetstone. You are an ass, do you see? touch any man here, and by&H4; this hand, I will&H1; run my rapier to&H4; the hilts in&H4; you.

div2.stage: They all draw, and they of the house make out to part them.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Yea, that&H62; would I fain see, boy.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: O Jesu! murder. Thomas, Gaspar!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Help, help, Thomas.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Gentlemen, forbear, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Well, sirrah, you, Holofernes: by&H4; my hand, I will&H1; pink your flesh, full of holes, with my rapier for&H4; this; I will&H1;, by&H4; this good heaven: They-offer to fight againe, and are parted. Nay, let him come, let him come, gentlemen, by&H4; the body of Saint George, I will&H1; not kill him.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: You whoreson, bragging coy strill!

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene III.
To them.

sp.speaker: Kitely.
sp.l: Why, how now? what is the matter? what is the stir here?
Whence springs the quarrel? Thomas! where is he?
Put up&H5; your weapons, and put off this rage.
My wife and sister, they are cause of this,
What, Thomas? where is this knave?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, let us&Htp; go: this is one of my brothers ancient humours, this.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I am glad, nobody was hurt by&H4; his ancient humour.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Why, how now, brother, who&H62; enforced this brawl?

sp.speaker: Dow.
Brid.
sp.l: Brother, indeed, you are too violent,
Too sudden, in&H4; your humour: and, you know
My brother Wel-breds temper will&H1; not bear
Any reproof, chiefly in&H4; such a presence,
Where every slight disgrace, he should receive,
Might wound him in&H4; opinion, and respect.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: Respect? what talk you of respect among such,
As have nor spark of manhood, nor good manners?
'Sdeynes I am ashamed, to&H9; hear you! respect?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: Yes, there was one a civil gentleman,
[25] And very worthily demeaned himself!

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: O, that&H62; was some love of yours, sister!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: A love of mine? I would it were no&H2; worse, brother!
You would pay my portion sooner, than you think for&H5;.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Indeed, he seemed to&H9; be a gentleman of an exceeding fair disposition, and of very excellent good parts!

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Her&H2; love, by&H4; heaven! my wifes minion!
Fair disposition? excellent good parts?
Death, these phrases are into intolerable!
Good parts? how should she know his parts?
His parts? Well, well, well, well, well, well!
It is too plain, too clear: Thomas, come hither.
What, are they gone?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Aye, sir, they went in&H5;.
My mistress, and your sister---

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Are any of the gallants within!

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: No&H7;, sir, they are all gone.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Art thou sure of it?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: I can assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: What gentleman was that&H62; they praised so&H52;, Thomas?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: One, they call him master Kno'well, a handsome young gentleman, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Aye, I thought so&H52;: my mind gave me as much.
I will&H1; die, but they have hid him in&H4; the house,
Somewhere; I will&H1; go and search: go with me, Thomas.
[50] Be true to&H4; me, and thou shalt find me a master.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene IIII.
Cob, Tib:

sp.p: What Tib, Tib, I say.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: How now, what cuckold is that&H62; knocks so&H51; hard? O, husband, is it you? what is the news?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, you have from stunned me, I'faith! you have given me a knock on&H4; the forehead, will&H1; stick by&H4; me! cuckold? 'Slid, cuckold?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p:
Away, you fool, did I know it was you, that&H61; knocked?
Come, come, you may call me as bad, when you list.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: May I? Tib, you are a whore.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: You lie in&H4; your throat, husband.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How, the lie? and in&H4; my throat too? do you long to&H9; be stabbed, ha?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why, you are no&H2; soldier, I hope?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, must you be stabbed by&H4; a soldier? Mass, that&H62; is true! when was Bobadill here? your Captain? that&H62; rogue, that&H62; foist, that&H62; fencing Burgullian? I will&H1; tickle him, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter? trow!

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, he has basted me, rarely, sumptuously! but I have it here in&H4; black and white; for&H4; his black, and blue: shall pay him. O, the Justice! the honestest old brave Trojan in&H4; London! I do honour the very flea of his dog. A plague on&H4; him though, he put me once in&H4; a villainous filthy fear; marry, it vanished away, like&H4; the smoke of tobacco: but I was smoked soundly first. I thank the devil, and his good angel, my guest. Well, wife, or Tib (which&H61; you will&H1;) get you in&H5;, and lock the door, I charge you, let nobody in&H5; to&H4; you; wife, nobody in&H5;, to&H4; you: those are my words. Not [25] Captain Bob himselfe, nor the fiend, in&H4; his likeness; you are a woman; you have flesh and blood enough in&H4; you, to&H9; be tempted: therefore, keep the door, shut, upon&H4; all comers.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I warrant you, there shall nobody enter here, without my consent.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nor, with your consent, sweet Tib, and so&H3; I leave you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: It is more, than you know, whether you leave me so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why, sweet.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Tut, sweet, or sour, thou art a flower,
Keep close thy door, I ask no&H2; more.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene V.
Ed. Kno'well, Well-bred, Stephen, Brayne-worme.

sp.p: Well Brayne-worme, perform this business, happily, And thou makest a purchase of my love, forever,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I'faith, now let thy spirits use their best faculties. but, at any hand, remember the message, to&H4; my brother: for&H3;, there is no&H2; other means, to&H9; start him.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I warrant you, sir, fear nothing: I have a nimble soul has waked all forces of my fantasy, by&H4; this time, and put them in&H4; true motion. What you have possessed me withal, I will&H1; discharge it amply, sir. Make it no&H2; question.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Forth, and prosper, Brayne-worme. Faith, Ned, how dost thou approve of my abilities in&H4; this devise?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Troth, well, howsoever: but, it will&H1; come excellent, if it take.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Take, man? why, it cannot choose but take, if the circumstances miscarry not: but, tell me, ingenuously, dost thou affect my sister Bridget, as thou pretendest?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Friend, am I worth belief?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, do not protest. In&H4; faith, she is a maid of good ornament, and much modesty: and, except I conceived very worthily of her&H6;, thou shouldest not have her&H6;.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, that&H62; I am afraid will&H1; be a question yet, whether I shall have her&H6;, or no&H5;?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'slid, thou shalt have her&H6;; by&H4; this light, thou shalt.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, do not swear.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By&H4; this hand, thou shalt have her&H6;: I will&H1; go fetch her&H6;, presently. [25] Point, but where to&H9; meet, and as I am an honest man, I will&H1; bring her&H6;.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Hold, hold, be temperate.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, by&H4;---what shall I swear by&H5;? thou shalt have her&H6;, as I am---

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Pray thee, be at peace, I am satisfied: and do believe, thou wilt omit no&H2; offered occasion, to&H9; make my desires complete.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Thou shalt see, and know, I will&H1; not.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene VI.
Formall, Kno'well, Brayne-worme.

sp.p: Was your man a soldier, sir?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Aye, a knave, I took him begging on&H4; the way,
This morning, as I came over More-fields!
O, here he is! you have made fair speed, believe me:
Where, in&H4; the name of sloth, could you be thus---

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Marry, peace be my comfort, where I thought I should have had little comfort of your worships service.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: How so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, sir! your coming to&H4; the city, your entertainment of me, and your sending me to&H9; watch--- indeed, all the circumstances either of your charge, or my employment, are as open to&H4; your son, as to&H4; yourself!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: How should that&H62; be! unless that&H62; villain, Brayne-worme,
Have told him of the letter, and discovered
All that&H61; I strictly charged him to&H9; conceal? it is so&H52;!

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I am, partly, of the faith, it is so&H52; indeed.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: But, how should he know thee to&H9; be my man?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nay, sir, I cannot tell; unless it be by&H4; the black art! Is not your son a scholar, sir?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Yes, but I hope his soul is not allied
Unto such hellish practise: if it were,
I had just cause to&H9; weep my part in&H4; him,
And curse the time of his creation.
But, where didst thou find them, Fitz-Sword?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: [25] You should rather ask, where they found me, sir, for&H3;, I will&H1; be sworn I was going along in&H4; the street, thinking nothing, when (of a sudden) a voice calls, M r. Kno-wel's man; another cries, soldier: and thus, half a dozen of them, till they had called me within a house where I no&H2; sooner came, but thy seemed men, and out flue all their rapiers at my bosom, with some three or four score oaths to&H9; accompany them, & all to&H9; tell me, I was but a dead man, if I did not confess where you were, and how I was employed, and about what; which&H61;, when they could not get out of me (as I protest, they must have dissected, and made an Anatomy of me, first, and so&H3; I told them) they locked me up&H5; into a room in&H4; the top of a high house, whence, by&H4; great miracle (having a light heart) I slid down, by&H4; a bottom of pack thread, into the street, and so&H3; scaped. But, sir, thus much I can assure you, for&H3; I heard it, while I was locked up&H5;, there were a great many rich merchants, and brave citizens wives with them at a feast, and your son, M r. Edward, with-drew with one of them, and has pointed to&H9; meet her&H6; anon, at one Cobs house, a water-bearer, that&H61; dwells by&H4; the wall. Now, there, your worship shall be sure to&H9; take him, for&H3; there he preys, and fail he will&H1; not.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Nor, will&H1; I fail, to&H9; break his match, I doubt not.
Go thou, along with Justice Clement's man,
And stay there for&H4; me. At one Cobs house, sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Aye sir, there you shall have him. Yes? Invisible? Much wench, or much son! 'Slight, when he has staid there, three or four hours, travelling with the expectation of wonders, and at length be delivered of air: O, the sport, that&H61; I should then take, to&H9; look on&H4; him, if I durst! But, [50] now, I mean to&H9; appear no&H2; more afore him in&H4; this shape. I have another trick, to&H9; act, yet. O, that&H3; I were so&H51; happy, as to&H9; light on&H4; a nupson, now, of this Justice's novice. Sir, I make you stay somewhat long.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: Not a whit, sir. Pray you, what do you mean? sir?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I was putting up&H5; some papers---

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: You have been lately in&H4; the wars, sir, it seems.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Marry have I, sir; to&H4; my loss: and expense of all, almost---

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: Troth sir, I would be glad to&H9; bestow a pottle of wine on&H4; you, if it please you to&H9; accept it---

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, sir---

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: But, to&H9; hear the manner of your services, and your devices in&H4; the wars, they say they be very strange, and not like&H4; those a man reads in&H4; the Roman histories, or sees, at Mile-end.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No&H7;, I assure you, sir, why, at any time when it please you, I shall be ready to&H9; discourse to&H4; you, all I know: and more too, somewhat.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: No&H2; better time, than now, sir; we&Htp; will&H1; go to&H4; the wind-mill: there we&Htp; shall have a cup of neat grist, we&Htp; call it. I pray you, sir, let me request you, to&H4; the wind-mill.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I will&H1; follow you, sir, and make grist of you, if I have good luck.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene VII.
Matthew, Ed. Kno'well, Bobadill, Stephen, Downe-right.
To them.

sp.p: Sir, did your eyes ever taste the like&H2; clown of him, where we&Htp; were today, M r. Wel-bred's half brother? I think, the whole earth cannot show his parallel, by&H4; this day-light.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: We&Htp; were now speaking of him: Captain Bobadil tells me, he is fallen foul of you, too.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, Aye, sir, he threatened me, with the bastinado.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Aye, but I think, I taught you prevention, this morning, for&H4; that&H62;--- You shall kill him, beyond question: if you be so&H51; generously minded.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Indeed, it is a most excellent trick!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: O, you do not give spirit enough, to&H4; your motion, you are too He practises at a post. tardy, too heavy! O, it must be done like&H4; lightning, hey?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Rare Captain!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Tut, it is nothing, if it be not done in&H4; a--- punto !

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Captain, did you ever prove yourself, upon&H4; any of our&Htp; masters of defence, here?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, good sir! yes, I hope, he has.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I will&H1; tell you, sir. Upon&H4; my first coming to&H4; the city, after my long travail, for&H4; knowledge (in&H4; that&H62; mystery only) there came three, or four of them to&H4; me, at a gentleman's house, where it was my chance to&H9; be resident, at that&H62; time, to&H9; entreat my presence at their schools, and withal so&H51; much importuned me, that&H3; (I protest to&H4; you as I am a gentleman) I was ashamed of their rude demeanour, out of all measure: well, I told them, that&H3; to&H9; come to&H4; a public school, they should pardon me, it was opposite (in&H4; diameter) to&H4; my humour, but, if so&H52; they would give their attendance [25] at my lodging, I protested to&H9; do them what right or favour I could, as I was a gentleman, and so&H52; forth.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: So&H3;, sir, then you tried their skill?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Alas, soon, tried! you shall hear sir. Within two or three days after, they came; and, by&H4; honesty, fair sir, believe me, I graced them exceedingly, showed them some two or three tricks of prevention, have purchased them since, a credit, to&H4; admiration! they cannot deny this: and yet now, they hate me, and why? because I am excellent, and for&H4; no&H2; other vile reason on&H4; the earth.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: This is strange, and barbarous! as ever I heard!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Nay, for&H4; a more instance of their preposterous natures, but note, sir. They have assaulted me some three, four, five, six of them together, as I have walked alone, in&H4; divers skirts in&H4; the town, as Turnebull, White-chappell, Shore-ditch, which&H61; were then my quarters, and since upon&H4; the Exchange, at my lodging, and at my ordinary: where I have driven them afore me, the whole length of a street, in&H4; the open view of all our&Htp; gallants, pitying to&H9; hurt them, believe me. Yet, all this lenity will&H1; not overcome their spleen: they will&H1; be doing with the pismire, raising a hill, a man may spurn abroad, with his foot, at pleasure. By&H4; myself, I could have slain them all, but I delight not in&H4; murder. I am loath to&H9; bear any other than this bastinado for&H4; them: yet, I hold it good polity, not to&H9; go disarmed, for&H3; though I be skilful, I may be oppressed with multitudes.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Aye, believe me, may you sir: and (in&H4; my conceit) our&Htp; whole nation should sustain the loss by&H4; it, if it were so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: [50] Alas, no&H7;: what is a peculiar man, to&H4; a nation? not seen.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, but your skill, sir!

sp.speaker: Bob.
E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, I know not, nor can I conceive.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why thus, sir. I would select nineteen, more, to&H4; myself, throughout the land; gentlemen they should be of good spirit, strong, and able constitution, I would choose them by&H4; an instinct, a character, that&H61; I have: and I would teach these nineteen, the special rules, as your Pants, your Reverso, your Stoccata, your Imbroccata, your Passada, your Montanso: till they could all play very near, or altogether as well as myself. This done, say the enemy were forty thousand strong, we&Htp; twenty would come into the field, the tenth of March, or thereabouts; and we&Htp; would challenge twenty of the enemy; they could not, in&H4; their honour, refuse us&Htp;, well, we&Htp; would kill them: challenge twenty more, kill them; twenty more, kill them; twenty more, kill them too; and thus, would we&Htp; kill, every man, his twenty a day, that&H62; is twenty score; twenty score, that&H62; is two hundredth; two hundredth a day, five days a thousand; forty thousand; forty times five, five times forty, two hundredth days kills them [75] all up&H5;, by&H4; computation. And this, will&H1; I venture my poor gentleman-like carcass, to&H9; perform (provided, there be no&H2; treason practised upon&H4; us&Htp;) by&H4; fair, and discreet manhood, that&H62; is, civilly by&H4; the sword.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Why, are you so&H51; sure of your hand, Captain, at all times?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Tut, never miss thrust, upon&H4; my reputation with you.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: I would not stand in&H4; Downe-rights state, then, if you meet him, for&H4; the wealth of any one street in&H4; London.

sp.speaker: Bob.
Mat.
sp.p: Faith, and I will&H1; have a fling at him, at my distance.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Gods son, look, where he is: yonder he goes.

div2.stage: Downe-right walkes ouer the stage.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: What peevish luck have I, I cannot meet with these bragging rascals?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: It is not he? is it?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Yes faith, it is he?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I will&H1; be hanged, then, if that&H62; were he.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Sir, keep your hanging good, for&H4; some greater matter, for&H3; I assure you, that&H62; was he.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Upon&H4; my reputation, it was he.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Had I thought it had been he, he must not have gone so&H52;: but I can hardly be induced, to&H9; believe, it was he, yet.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: That&H62; I think, sir. But see, he is come again!

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: O, Pharoahs foot, have I found you? Come, draw, to&H4; your [100] tools: draw, gypsy, or I will&H1; thresh you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Gentleman of valour, I do believe in&H4; thee, hear me---

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Draw your weapon, then.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Tall man, I never thought on&H4; it, till now (body of me) I had a warrant of the peace, served on&H4; me, even now, as I came along, by&H4; a water-bearer; this gentleman saw it, M r. Matthew.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you will&H1; not draw, then?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Hold, hold, under thy favour, forbear.

div2.stage: He beates him, and disarmes him: Matthew runnes away.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Prate again, as you like&H1; this, you whoreson foist, you. You will&H1; control the point, you? Your consort is gone? had he staid, he had shared with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, bear witness, I was bound to&H4; the peace, by&H4; this good day.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: No&H7; faith, it is an ill day, Captain, never reckon it other: but, say you were bound to&H4; the peace, the law allows you, to&H9; defend yourself: that&H62; will&H1; prove but a poor excuse.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I cannot tell, sir. I desire good construction, in&H4; fair sort. I never sustained the like&H2; disgrace (by&H4; heaven) sure I was struck with a planet thence, for&H3; I had no&H2; power to&H9; touch my weapon.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p:
Aye, like&H5; enough, I have heard of many that&H61; have been beaten under a planet: go, get you to&H4; a surgeon. 'Slid, if these be your tricks, your passada's, and your mountanto's, I will&H1; none of them. O, manners! that&H3;
this age should bring forth such creatures! that&H3; Nature should be at leisure to&H9; make hem! Come, cuz.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Mass, I will&H1; have this cloak.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: [125] Gods will&H0;, it is Downe-right's.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, it is mine now, another might have taken up&H5;, as well as I: I will&H1; wear it, so&H52; I will&H1;.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How, if he see it? he will&H1; challenge it, assure yourself.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Aye, but he shall not have it; I will&H1; say, I bought it.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Take heed, you buy it not, too dear, cuz.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene VIII.
Kitely, Wel-bred, Dame Kit. Bridget, Brayne-worme, Cash.

sp.l: Now, trust me brother, you were much to&H9; blame,
To&H9; incense his anger, and disturb the peace,
Of my poor house, where there are sentinels,
That&H61; every minute watch, to&H9; give alarms,
Of civil war, without adjection
Of your assistance, or occasion.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No&H2; harm done, brother, I warrant you: since there is no&H2; harm done. Anger costs a man nothing: and a tall man is never his own man, till he be angry. To&H9; keep his valour in&H4; obscurity, is to&H9; keep himself, as it were, in&H4; a cloak-bag. What is musician, unless he play? what is a tall man, unless he fight? For&H3;, indeed, all this, my wise brother stands upon&H5;, absolutely: and, that&H62; made me fall in&H5; with him, so&H51; resolutely.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Aye, but what harm might have come of it, brother?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Might, sister? so&H52;, might the good warm clothes, your husband wears, be poisoned, for&H4; anything he knows: or the wholesome wine he drunk, even now, at the table---

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Now, god forbid: O me. Now, I remember,
My wife drunk to&H4; me, last; and changed the cup:
And bade me wear this cursed suit today.
See, if heaven suffer murder undiscovered!
I feele me ill; give me some mithridate,
Some mithridate and oil, good sister, fetch me;
O, I am sick at heart! I burn, I burn.
If you will&H1; save my life, go, fetch it me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: [25] O, strange humour! my very breath has poisoned him.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: Good brother, be content, what do you mean?
The strength of these extreme conceits, will&H1; kill you.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p:
Beshrew your heart-blood, brother Well-bred, now;
for&H4; putting such a toy into his head.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Is a fit smile, a toy? will&H1; he be poisoned with a simile? Brother Kitely, what a strange, and idle imagination is this? For&H4; shame, be wiser, O my soul, there is no&H2; such matter.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Am I not sick? how am I, then, not poisoned?
Am I not poisoned? how am I, then, so&H51; sick?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: If you be sick, your own thoughts make you sick.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: His jealousy is the poison, he has taken.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: M r. Kitely, my master, Justice Clement, salutes you; and desires to&H9; speak with you, with all possible speed.

div2.stage: He comes disguis'd like Justice Clements man.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: No&H2; time, but now? when, I think, I am sick? very sick! well, I will&H1; wait upon&H4; his worship. Thomas, Cob, I must seek them out, and set them sentinels, till I return. Thomas, Cob, Thomas.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This is perfectly rare, Brayne-worme! but how gottest thou this apparel, of the Justice's man?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Marry sir, my proper fine pen-man, would needs bestow the grift on&H4; me, at the wind-mil, to&H9; hear some martial discourse; where so&H52; I marshalled him, that&H3; I made him drunk, with admiration! &, because, too much heat was the cause of his distemper, I stripped him stark naked, as he lay along asleep, and borrowed his suit, to&H9; deliver this counterfeit message in&H5;, leaving a rusty armour, and an old brown bill to&H9; watch him, till my return:[50] which&H61; shall be, when I have pawned his apparel, and spent the better part of the money, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, thou art a successful merry knave, Brayne-worme, his absence will&H1; be a good subject for&H4; more mirth. I pray thee, return to&H4; thy young master, and will&H1; him to&H9; meet me, and my sister Bridget, at the tower instantly: for&H3;, here, tell him, the house is so&H51; stored with jealousy, there is no&H2; room for&H4; love, to&H9; stand upright in&H5;. We&Htp; must get our&Htp; fortunes committed to&H4; some larger prison, say; and, then the tower, I know no&H2; better air: nor where the liberty of the house may do us&Htp; more present service. Away.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Come hither, Thomas. Now, my secret is ripe,
And thou shalt have it: lay to&H5; both thine ears.
Hark, what I say to&H4; thee. I must go forth, Thomas.
Be careful of thy promise, keep good watch,
Note every gallant, and observe him well,
That&H61; enters in&H4; my absence, to&H4; thy mistress:
If she would show him rooms, the jest is stale,
Follow them, Thomas, or else hang on&H4; him,
And let him not go after; mark their looks;
Note, if she offer but to&H9; see his band,
Or any other amorous toy, about him;
But praise his leg; or foot; or if she say,
The day is hot, and bid him feele her&H2; hand,
How hot it is; O, that&H62; is a monstrous thing!
Note me all this, good Thomas, mark their sighs,
[75] And, if they do but whisper, break them off:
I will&H1; bear thee out in&H4; it. Wilt thou do this?
Wilt thou be true, my Thomas?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: As truth's self, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Why, I believe thee: where is Cob, now? Cob?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: He is ever calling for&H4; Cob! I wonder, how he employs Cob, so&H52;!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Indeed, sister, to&H9; ask how he employs Cob, is a necessary question for&H4; you, that&H61; are his wife, and a thing not very easy for&H4; you to&H9; be satisfied in&H5;: but this I will&H1; assure you, Cobs wife is an excellent bawd, sister, and, often-times, your husband haunts her&H2; house, marry, to&H4; what end, I cannot altogether accuse him, imagine you what you think convenient. But, I have known, fair hides have foul hearts, ere now, sister.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Never said you truer than that&H62;, brother, so&H51; much I can tell you for&H4; your learning. Thomas, fetch your cloak, and go with me, I will&H1; after him presently: I would to&H4; fortune, I could take him there, i'faith. I would return him his own, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: So&H3;, let them go: this may make sport anon. Now, my fair sister in-law, that&H3; you knew, but how happy a thing it were to&H9; be fair, and beautiful?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: That&H62; touches not me, brother.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: That&H62; is true; that&H62; is even the fault of it: for&H3;, indeed, beauty stands a woman in&H4; no&H2; stead, unless it procure her&H2; touching. But, sister, whether it touch you, or no&H5;, it touches your beauties; and, I am sure, they will&H1; abide the touch; if they do not, a plague of all ceruse, say I: and, it [100] touches me too in&H4; part, though not in&H4; the---Well, there is a dear and respected friend of mine, sister, stands very strongly, and worthily affected toward you, and hath vowed to&H9; inflame whole bone-fires of zeal, at his heart, in&H4; honour of your perfections. I have already engaged my promise to&H9; bring you, where you shall hear him confirm much more. Ned Kno'well is the man, sister. There is no&H2; exception against the party. You are ripe for&H4; a husband; and a minutes loss to&H4; such an occasion, is a great trespass in&H4; wise beauty. What say you, sister? On&H4; my soul he loves you. Will&H1; you give him the meeting?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Faith, I had very little confidence in&H4; mine own constancy, brother, if I durst not meet a man: but this motion of yours, savours of an old knight-adventurers servant, a little too much, methinks.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What is that&H62;, sister?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Marry, of the squire.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No&H2; matter if it did, I would be such an one for&H4; my friend, but see! who&H62; is returned to&H9; hinder us&Htp;?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: What villainy is this? called out on&H4; a false message?
This was some plot! I was not sent for&H5;. Bridget,
Where is your sister?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: I think she be gone forth, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: How! is my wife gone forth? whether for&H4; gods sake?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: She is gone abroad with Thomas.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Abroad with Thomas? O, that&H62; villain dors me.
He hath discovered all unto my wife!
Beast that&H61; I was, to&H9; trust him: whither, I pray you, went she?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: [125] I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I will&H1; tell you, brother, whither I suspect she is gone.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Whither, good brother?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: To&H4; Cobs house, I believe: but, keep my counsel.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: I will&H1;, I will&H1;: to&H4; Cobs house? doth she haunt Cobs?
She is gone of purpose, now, to&H9; cuckold me,
With that&H62; lewd rascal, who&H61;, to&H9; win her&H2; favour,
Hath told her&H6; all.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, he is once more gone. Sister, let us&Htp; loose no&H2; time; the affair is worth it.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene IX.
Matthew, Bobadil, Brayne-worme, Down-right.
To them.

sp.p: I wonder, Captain, what they will&H1; say of my going away? ha?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why, what should they say? but as of a discreet gentleman? quick, wary, respectful of natures fair lineaments: and that&H62; is all?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why, so&H52;! but what can they say of your beating?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A rude part, a touch with soft wood, a kind of gross battery used, laid on&H5; strongly, borne most patiently: and that&H62; is all.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Aye, but, would any man have offered it in&H4; Venice? as you say?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Tut, I assure you, no&H7;: you shall have there your Nobilis, your Gentelezza, come in&H5; bravely upon&H4; your reverse, stand you close, stand you firm, stand you fair, save your retricato with his left leg, come to&H4; the assalto with the right, thrust with brave steel, defy your base wood! But, wherefore do I awake this remembrance? I was fascinated, by&H4; Jupiter: Fascinated: but I will&H1; be un-witched, and revenged, by&H4; law.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Do you hear? is it not best to&H9; get a warrant, and have him arrested, and brought before Justice Clement?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: It were not amiss, would we&Htp; had it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why, here comes his man, let us&Htp; speak to&H4; him.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Agreed, do you speak.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Save you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: With all my heart, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Sir, there is one Downe-right, hath abused this gentleman, and myself, and we&Htp; determine to&H9; make our&Htp; amends by&H4; law; now, if you would do us&Htp; the favour, to&H9; procure a warrant, to&H9; bring him afore your
master, you shall be well considered, I assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: [25] Sir, you know my service is my living, such favours as these, gotten of my master, is his only preferment, and therefore, you must consider me, as I may make benefit of my place.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How is that&H62;? sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith sir, the thing is extraordinary, and the gentleman may be, of great accompt: yet, be what he will&H1;, if you will&H1; lay me down a brace of angels, in&H4; my hand, you shall have it, otherwise not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How shall we&Htp; do, Captain? he asks a brace of angels, you have no&H2; money?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Not a cross, by&H4; fortune.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Nor I, as I am a gentleman, but two pence, left of my two shillings in&H4; the morning for&H4; wine, and radish: let us&Htp; find him some pawn.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Pawn? we&Htp; have none to&H4; the value of his demand.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, yes. I will&H1; pawn this jewel in&H4; my ear, and you may pawn your silk stockings, and pull up&H5; your boots, they will&H1; never be missed: It must be done, now.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Well, if there be no&H2; remedy: I will&H1; step aside, and pull them off.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Do you hear, sir? we&Htp; have no&H2; store of money at this time, but you shall have good pawns: look you, sir, this jewel, and that&H62; gentleman's silk stockings, because we&Htp; would have it dispatched, ere we&Htp; went to&H4; our&Htp; chambers.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I am content, sir; I will&H1; get you the warrant presently, what is his name, say you? Downe-right?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, George Downe-right.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: [50] A tall big man, sir; he goes in&H4; a cloak, most commonly, of silk russet, laid about with russet lace.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: It is very good, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Here sir, here is my jewel?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: And, here, are stockings.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, I will&H1; procure you this warrant presently, but, who&H62; will&H1; you have to&H9; serve it?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That&H62; is true, Captain: that&H62; must be considered.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Body of me, I know not! it is service of danger?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Why, you were best get one of the varlets of the city, a sergeant. I will&H1; appoint you one, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Will&H1; you, sir? why, we&Htp; can wish no&H2; better.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: We&Htp; will&H1; leave it to&H4; you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: This is rare! now, will&H1; I go pawn this cloak of the Justice's man's, at the brokers, for&H4; a varlets suit, and be the varlet myself; and get either more pawns, or more money of Downe-right, for&H4; the arrest.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene X.
Kno'wel, Tib, Cash, Dame Kitely, Kitely, Cob.

sp.l: O, here it is, I am glad: I have found it now.
Ho? who&H62; is within, here?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I am within, sir, what is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: To&H9; know, who&H61; is within, besides yourself.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why, sir, you are no&H2; constable, I hope?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: O! fear you the constable? then, I doubt not.
You have some guests within, deserve that&H62; fear,
I will&H1; fetch him straight.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Of gods name, sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Go to&H5;. Come, tell me, Is not young Kno'wel, here?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Young Kno-wel? I know none such, sir, of mine honesty!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Your honesty? dame, it flies too lightly from you:
There is no&H2; way, but, fetch the constable.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: The constable? the man is mad, I think.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Ho, who&H62; keeps house, here?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: O, this is the female copes-mate of my son?
Now shall I meet him straight.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Knock, Thomas, hard.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Ho, good wife?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Why, woman, grieves it you to&H9; open your door?
Belike, you get something, to&H9; keep it shut.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: What mean these questions, pray ye?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: So&H51; strange you make it? is not my husband, here?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: [25] Her&H2; husband!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: My tried husband, master Kitely.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I hope, he needs not to&H9; betryed, here.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: No&H7;, dame: he does it not for&H4; need, but pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Neither for&H4; need, nor pleasure, is he here.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: This is but a device, to&H9; balk the withal.
Soft, who&H62; is this? It is not my son, disguised?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: O, sir, have I forestalled your honest market?
sp.stage: Shee spies her husband come: and runnes to him.
sp.l: Found your close walks? you stand amazed, now, do you?
I'faith (I am glad) I have smoked you yet at last!
What is your jewel trow? In&H5;: come, let us&Htp; see her&H6;;
(Fetch forth your housewife, dame) if she be fairer,
In&H4; any honest judgment, than myself,
I will&H1; be content with it: but, she is change,
She feeds you fat, she soothes your appetite,
And you are well? your wife, an honest woman,
Is meat twice sod to&H4; you, sir? O, you treacher!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: She cannot counterfeit thus palpably.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Out on&H4; thy more than strumpets impudence!
Stealest thou thus to&H4; thy haunts? and, have I taken
Thy bawd, and thee, and thy companion,
This hoary-headed lecher, this old goat,
Close at your villainy, and wouldst thou excuse it,
With this stale harlots jest, accusing me?
O, old incontinent, dost not thou shame,
[50] When all thy powers in&H4; chastity is spent,
To&H9; have a mind so&H51; hot? and to&H9; entice,
And feed the enticements of a lustful woman?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Out, I defy thee, Aye, dissembling wretch.
By&H4; Thomas.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Defy me, strumpet? ask thy pander, here,
Can he deny it? or that&H62; wicked elder?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Why, hear you, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Tut, tut, tut: never speak.
Thy guilty conscience will&H1; discover thee.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: What lunacy is this, that&H61; haunts this man?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Well, good-wife B A'D, Cobs wife; and you,
That&H61; make your husband such a hoddie-doddie;
And you, young apple-squire; and old cuckold-maker;
I will&H1; have you every one before a Justice:
Nay, you shall answer it, I charge you go.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Marry, with all my heart, sir: I go willingly.
Though I do taste this as a trick, put on&H4; me,
To&H9; punish my impertinent search; and justly:
And half forgive my son, for&H4; the device.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Come, will&H1; you go?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Go? to&H4; thy shame, believe it.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter, here? What is here to&H9; do?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: O, Cob, art thou come? I have been abused,
And in&H4; thy house. Never was man so&H52;, wronged!

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: 'slid, in&H4; my house? my master Kitely? Who&H62; wrongs you in&H4; [75] my house?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Marry, young lust in&H4; old; and old in&H4; young, here:
Thy wife's their bawd, here have I taken them.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How? bawd? Is my house come to&H4; that&H62;? Am I preferred thither? He falls vpon his wife and beates her. Did I charge you to&H9; keep your doors shut, Is'bel? and do you let them lie open for&H4; all comers?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Friend, know some cause, before thou beatest thy wife,
This is madness, in&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Why? is there no&H2; cause?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Yes, I will&H1; show cause before the Justice, Cob:
Come, let her&H6; go with me.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, she shall go.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Nay, I will&H1; go. I will&H1; see, if you may be allowed to&H9; make a bundle of hemp, of your right and lawful wife thus, at every cuckoldly knaves pleasure. Why do you not go?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: A bitter quean. Come, we&Htp; will&H1; have you tamed.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene XI.
Brayne-worme, Matthew, Bobadil, Stephen, Downe-right.

sp.p: Well, of all my disguises, yet, now am I most like&H4; myself: being in&H4; this Sergeants gown. A man of my present profession, never counterfeits, till he lays hold upon&H4; a debtor, and says, he rests him, for&H3; then he brings him to&H4; all manner of unrest. A kind of little kings we&Htp; are, bearing the diminutive of a mace, made like&H4; a young artichoke, that&H61; always carries pepper and salt, in&H4; itself. Well, I know not what danger I undergo, by&H4; this exploit, pray heaven, I come well off.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: See, I think, yonder is the varlet, by&H4; his gown.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Let us&Htp; go, in&H4; quest of him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Save you, friend, are not you here, by&H4; appointment of Justice Clements man.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Yes, if it please you, sir: he told me two gentlemen had willed him to&H9; procure a warrant from his master (which&H61; I have about me) to&H9; be served on&H4; one Downe-right.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: It is honestly done of you both; and see, where the party comes, you must arrest: serve it upon&H4; him, quickly, afore he be aware---

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Bear back, master Matthew.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master Downe-right, I arrest you, in&H4; the queens name, and must carry you afore a Justice, by&H4; virtue of this warrant.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Me, friend? I am no&H2; Downe-right, I. I am master Stephen, you do not well, to&H9; arrest me, I tell you, truly: I am in&H4; nobodies bonds, nor books, I, would you should know it. A plague on&H4; [25] you heartily, for&H4; making me thus afraid afore my time.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Why, now are you deceived, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: He wears such a cloak, and that&H62; deceived us&Htp;: But see, here he comes, indeed! this is he, officer.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Why, how now, signior gull! are you turned filcher of late? come, deliver my cloak.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Your cloak, sir? I bought it, even now, in&H4; open market.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master Dovvne-right, I have a warrant I must serve upon&H4; you, procured by&H4; these two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: These gentlemen? these rascals?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Keep the peace, I charge you, in&H4; her&H2; Majesty's name.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I obey thee. What must I do, officer?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Go before, master Justice Clement, to&H9; answer what they can object against you, sir. I will&H1; use you kindly, sir.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Come, let us&Htp; before, and make the Justice, Captaine---

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: The varlet's a tall man! afore heaven!

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Gull, you will&H1; give me my cloak?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Sir, I bought it, and I will&H1; keep it.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: You will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Aye, that&H62; I will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Officer, there is thy fee, arrest him.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master Stephen, I must arrest you.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Arrest me, I scorn it. There, take your cloak, I will&H1; none of it.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Nay, that&H62; shall not serve your turn, now, sir. Officer, I will&H1; [50] go with thee, to&H4; the Justices: bring him along.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, is not here your cloak? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I will&H1; have you answer it, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, I will&H1; take your word; and this gentleman's, too: for&H4; his appearance.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I will&H1; have no&H2; words taken. Bring him along.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, I may choose, to&H9; do that&H62;: I may take bail.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: It is true, you may take bail, and choose; at another time: but you shall not, now, varlet. Bring him along, or I will&H1; swing you.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, I pity the gentleman's case. Here is your money again.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: 'Sdeynes, tell not me of my money, bring him away, I say.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I warrant you he will&H1; go with you of himself, sir.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Yet more ado?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I have made a fair mash of it.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Must I go?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I know no&H2; remedy, master Stephen.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Come along, afore me, here. I do not love your hanging look behind.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, sir. I hope you cannot hang me for&H4; it. Can he, fellow?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I think not, sir. It is but a whipping matter, sure!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, then, let him do his worst, I am resolute.

div2.stage:
Act V.
Scene I.
Clement, Kno'wel, Kitely, Dame Kitely, Tib, Cash, Cob, Servants.

sp.p: Nay, but stay, stay, give me leave: my chair, sirrah. You, master Kno'well, say you went thither to&H9; meet your son.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Aye, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But, who&H62; directed you, thither?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: That&H62; did mine own man, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Nay, I know not, now; I left him with your clarke:
And appointed him, to&H9; stay here for&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: My clarke? about what time, was this?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Marry, between one and two, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And, what time came my man with the false message to&H4; you, master Kitely?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: After two, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Very good: but, mistress Kitely, how that&H61; you were at Cobs? ha?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: If please you, sir, I will&H1; tell you: my brother, Wel-bred, told me, that&H3; Cobs house, was a suspected place---

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: So&H52; it appears, methinks: but, on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And that&H3; my husband used thither, daily.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No&H2; matter, so&H3; he used himself well, mistress.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: True sir, but you know, what grows, by&H4; such haunts, often-times.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I see, rank fruits of a jealous brain, mistress Kitely: but, did you find your husband there, in&H4; that&H62; case, as you suspected?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: I found her&H6; there, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: [25] Did you so&H52;? that&H62; alters the case. Who&H62; gave you knowledge, of your wives being there?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Marry, that&H62; did my brother Wel-bred.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How? Wel-bred first tell her? then tell you, after? where is Wel-bred?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Gone with my sister, sir, I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Clem.
