sp.p: Why, this is a mere trick, a device; you are gulled in&H4; this most grossly, all! alas, poor wench, wert thou beaten for&H4; this?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Yes, most pitifully, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: And worthily, I hope: if it shall prove so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Aye, that&H62; is like&H5;, and a piece of a sentence. How now, sir? what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, there is a gentleman, in&H4; the court without, desires to&H9; speak with your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A gentleman? what is he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A soldier, sir, he says.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A soldier? take down my armour, my sword, quickly: a soldier He armes himselfe. speak with me! why, when knaves? come on&H5;, come on&H5;, hold my cap there, so&H3;; give me my gorget, my sword: stand by&H5;, I will&H1; end your matters, anon---Let the soldier enter, now, sir, what have you to&H9; say to&H4; me?

div2.stage:
Act V. Scene II.
Bobadill, Matthew.

sp.p: By&H4; your worships fauour---

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, keep out, sir, I know not your pretence, you send me word, sir, you are a soldier: why, sir, you shall be answered, here, here be them have been amongst soldiers. Sir, your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Faith, sir, so&H52; it is, this gentleman, and myself, have been most uncivilly wronged, and beaten, by&H4; one Downe-right, a course fellow, about the town, here, and for&H4; mine own part, I protest, being a man, in&H4; no&H2; sort, given to&H4; this filthy humour of quarrelling, he hath assaulted me in&H4; the way of my peace; dispoiled me of mine honour; disarmed me of my weapons; and rudely, laid me along, in&H4; the open streets: when, I not so&H51; much as once offered to&H9; resist him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: O, gods precious! is this the soldier? here, take my armour off quickly, it will&H1; make him swoon, I fear; he is not fit to&H9; look on&H4; it, that&H62; will&H1; put up&H5; a blow.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: If it please your worship, he was bound to&H4; the peace.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, if he were, sir, his hands were not bound, were they?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: There is one of the varlets of the city, sir, has brought two gentlemen, here, one, upon&H4; your worships warrant.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: My warrant?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, sir. The officer says, procured by&H4; these two.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Bid him, come in&H5;. Set by&H4; this picture. What, M r. Downe-right! are you brought at M r. Fresh-waters suite, here!

div2.stage:
Act V. Scene III.
Downe-right, Stephen, Brayne-worme.

sp.p: I'faith, sir. And here is another brought at my suite.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: A gentleman, sir? O, uncle!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Uncle? who&H62;? master Kno'well?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Aye, sir! this is a wise kinsman of mine.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: God is my witness, uncle, I am wronged here monstrously, he charges me with stealing of his cloak, and would I might never stir, if I did not find it in&H4; the street, by&H4; chance.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: O, did you find it, now? you said, you bought it, ere-while.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: And, you said, I stole it; nay, now my uncle is here, I will&H1; do well enough, with you.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, let this breath a while; you, that&H61; have cause to&H9; complain, there, stand forth: had you my warrant for&H4; this gentleman's apprehension?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Aye, if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, do not speak in&H4; passion so&H52;: where had you it?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Of your clarke, sir?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: That&H62; is well! if my clarke can make warrants, and my hand not at them! Where is the warrant? Officer, have you it?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No&H7;, sir, your worship's man, master Formal, bid me do it, for&H4; these gentlemen, and he would be my discharge.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, master Downe-right, are you such a novice, to&H9; be served, and never see the warrant?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Sir. He did not serve it on&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: [25] No&H7;? how then?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Marry, sir, he came to&H4; me, and said, he must serve it, and he would use me kindly, and so&H3;---

sp.speaker: Clem.

div2.stage: He flourishes ouer him with his long-sword.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, good sir, I beseech you; nay, good master Justice.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I must do it; there is no&H2; remedy. I must cut off your legs, sirrah, I must cut off your cares, you rascal, I must do it; I must cut off your nose, I must cut off your head.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, good your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, rise, how doest thou do, now? doest thou feele thyself well? hast thou no&H2; harm?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No&H7;, I thank your good worship, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, so&H52;! I said, I must cut off thy legs, and I must cut off thy arms, and I must cut off thy head; but, I did not do it: so&H3;, you said, you must serve this gentleman, with my warrant, but, you did not serve him. You knave, you slave, you rogue, do you say you must? sirrah, away with him, to&H4; the jail, I will&H1; teach you a trick, for&H4; your must, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Good, sir, I beseech you, be good to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Tell him he shall to&H4; the jail, away with him, I say.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nay, sir, if you will&H1; commit me, it shall be for&H4; committing more than this: I will&H1; not loose, by&H4; my travail, any grain of my fame certain.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: [50] How is this!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: My man, Brayne-worme!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O yes, uncle. Brayne-worme has been with my cousin Edward, and I, all this day.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I told you all, there was some device!

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nay, excellent Justice, since I have laid myself thus open to&H4; you; now, stand strong for&H4; me: both with your sword, and your balance.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Body of me, a merry knave! Give me a bowl of sack: If he belong to&H4; you, master Kno'well, I bespeak your patience.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: That&H62; is it, I have most need of. Sir, if you will&H1; pardon me, only; I will&H1; glory in&H4; all the rest, of my exploits.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Sir, you know, I love not to&H9; have my favours come hard, from me. You have your pardon: though I suspect you shrewdly for&H4; being of counsel with my son, against me.

sp.speaker: Bray.
Kno.
sp.p: Is it possible! or that&H3; thou shouldest disguise thy language so&H52;, as I should not know thee?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, sir, this has been the day of my metamorphosis! It is not that&H62; shape alone, that&H61; I have run through, today. I brought this gentleman, master Kitely, a message too, in&H4; the form of master Justice's man, here, to&H9; draw him out of the way, as well as your worship: while master [75] Well-bred might make a conveyance of mistress Bridget, to&H4; my young master.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: How! my sister stolen away?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: My son is not married, I hope!

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith, sir, they are both as sure as love, a priest, and three thousand pound (which&H61; is her&H2; portion) can make them: and by&H4; this time are ready to&H9; bespeak their wedding supper at the wind-mill, except some friend, here, prevent them, and invite them home.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Marry, that&H62; will&H1; I (I thank thee, for&H4; putting me in&H4; mind of it.) Sirrah, go you, and fetch them hither, upon&H4; my warrant. Neithers friends have cause to&H9; be sorry, if I know the young couple, aright. Here, I drink to&H4; thee, for&H4; thy good news. But, I pray thee, what hast thou done with my man Formall.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith, sir, after some ceremony past, as making him drunk, first with story, and then with wine (but all in&H4; kindness) and stripping him to&H4; his shirt: I left him in&H4; that&H62; cool vain, departed, sold your worships warrant to&H4; these two, pawned his livery for&H4; that&H62; varlets gown, to&H9; serve it in&H5;; and thus have brought myself, by&H4; my activity, to&H4; your worships consideration.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
And I will&H1; consider thee, in&H4; another cup of sack. Here is to&H4; thee, which&H61; having drunk of, this is my sentence. Pledge me. Thou hast done,
or assisted to&H4; nothing, in&H4; my judgment, but deserves to&H9; be pardoned for&H4; the wit of the offence. If thy master, or any man, here, be angry with thee, I shall suspect his engine, while I know him for&H4; it. How now? what noise is that&H62;!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: [100] Sir, it is Roger is come home.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Bring him in&H5;, bring him in&H5;. What! drunk in&H4; arms, against me? Your reason, your reason for&H4; this.

div2.stage:
Act V. Scene IIII.
Formall.
To them.

sp.p: I beseech your worship to&H9; pardon me; I happened into ill company by&H4; chance, that&H61; cast me into a sleep, and stripped me of all my clothes---

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, tell him, I am Justice Clement, and do pardon him: but, what is this to&H4; your armour! what may that&H62; signify?

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: If it please you, sir, it hung up&H5; in&H4; the room, where I was stripped; and I borrowed it of one of the drawers, to&H9; come home in&H5;, because I was loath, to&H9; do penance through the street, in&H4; my shirt.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, stand by&H5; a while. Who&H62; be these? O, the young company, welcome, welcome. Give you joy. Nay mistress Bridget, blush not; you are not so&H51; fresh a bride, but the news of it is come hither afore you. Master Bridegroom, I have made your peace, give me your hand: so&H52; will&H1; I for&H4; all the rest, ere you forsake my roof.

div2.stage:
Act V. Scene V.
Ed. Kno'wel, Wel-bred, Bridget.
To them.

sp.p: We&Htp; are the more bound to&H4; your humanity, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Only these two, have so&H51; little of man in&H4; them, they are no&H2; part of my care.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Yes, sir, let me pray you for&H4; this gentleman, he belongs, to&H4; my sister, the bride.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: In&H4; what place, sir?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Of her&H2; delight, sir, below the stairs, and in&H4; public: her&H2; poet, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.l: A poet? I will&H1; challenge him myself, presently, at extempore.
Mount up&H5; thy Phlegon muse, and testify,
How Saturn, sitting in&H4; an ebony cloud,
Disrobed his podex white as ivory,
And, through the welkin, thundered all aloud.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: He is not for&H4; extempore, sir. He is all for&H4; the pocket-muse, please you command a sight of it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes, yes, search him for&H4; a taste of his vein.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You must not deny the Queens Justice, Sir, under a writ of rebellion.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What! all this verse? Body of me, he carries a whole realm, a common-wealth of paper, in&H4; his hose! let us&Htp; see some of his subjects!
sp.l: Unto the boundless Ocean of thy face,
Runs this poor river charged with streams of eyes.
How? this is stolen!

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: A Parody! a parody! with a kind of miraculous gift, to&H9; make [25] it absurder than it was.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Is all the rest, of this batch? Bring me a torch; lay it together, and give fire. Cleanse the air. Here was enough to&H9; have infected, the whole city, if it had not been taken in&H4; time! See, see, how our&Htp; Poets glory shines! brighter, and brighter! still it increases! O, now, it is at the highest: and, now, it declines as fast. You may see. Sic transit gloria mundi.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: There is an emblem for&H4; you, son, and your studies!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, no&H2; speech, or act of mine be drawn against such as profess it worthily. They are not born every year, as an Alderman. There goes more to&H4; the making of a good Poet, than a Sheriff, M r. Kitely. You look upon&H4; me! though, I live in&H4; the city here, amongst you, I will&H1; do more reverence, to&H4; him, when I meet him, than I will&H1; to&H4; the Major, out of his year. But, these paper-peddlers! these ink-dabblers! They cannot expect reprehension, or reproach. They have it with the fact.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Sir, you have saved me the labour of a defence.

sp.speaker: Clem.
Step.
sp.p: And what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: O! I had lost a sheep, if he had not bleated! Why, sir, you [50] shall give Mr. Downe-right his cloak: and I will&H1; entreat him to&H9; take it. A trencher, and a napkin, you shall have, in&H4; the buttery, and keep Cob, and his wife company, here; whom, I will&H1; entreat first to&H9; be reconciled: and you to&H9; endeavour with your wit, to&H9; keep them so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I will&H1; do my best.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Why, now I see thou art honest, Tib, I receive thee as my dear, and mortal wife, again.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: And, I you, as my loving, and obedient husband.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Good complement! It will&H1; be their bridal night too. They
are married anew. Come, I conjure the rest, to&H9; put of all discontent. You, M r. Downe-right, your anger; you, master Kno'well, your cares; master Kitely, and his wife, their jealousy.
sp.l: For&H3;, I must tell you both, while that&H62; is fed,
Horns in&H4; the mind are worse than on&H4; the head.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Sir, thus they go from me, kiss me, sweet heart.
See, what a drove of horns fly, in&H4; the air,
Winged with my cleansed, and my credulous breath!
Watch them, suspicious eyes, watch, where they fall.
See, see! on&H4; heads, that&H61; think they have none at all!
O, what a plenteous world of this, will&H1; come!
When air rains horns, all may be sure of fame.
I have learned so&H51; much verse out of a jealous man's part, in&H4; a play.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: It is well, it is well! This night we&Htp; will&H1; dedicate to&H4; friendship, love, and laughter. Master bridegroom, take your bride, and lead: everyone, a fellow. Here is my mistress. Brayne-worme! to&H4; whom all [75] my addresses of courtship shall have their reference. Whose adventures, this day, when our&Htp; grand-children shall hear to&H9; be made a fable, I doubt not, but it shall find both spectators, and applause.

div2.stage: The End
